Inscryption-how to review

First off, if you love card builders, you'll love the game.
If you're a fan of games that go in unexpected directions, you'll love this game.

If you're someone like me who isnt into the card games-milage may vary. I mean don't get me wrong, it is correct when you hear things like "you dont have to know card builder games to enjoy it"....well yes......but then no.  The game is divided into acts. The first act really is a great way to get someone introduced into deck building, and its my favorite act. 

The other acts-esp second-really introduce new mechanics and stuff that arent covered in act one, and doesn't hand hold. Plus its....different. I am saying little as it is true that the less you know going into the game the better. But I wasnt a fan of the other acts as much as first one, and while the surprises and twists were cool....it just fell off for me. 

Its also relatively short-I was under impression it would be longer after 1st act, but rest of game kind of just goes by quickly. Id love to see a whole game like act 1 with the theming and the puzzles/storytelling mix. 

If you like cardbuilders and/or really weird games that go in unexpected directions storywise, then youll like this. Otherwise, milage will vary. I do recommend it, but would advise getting it on sale for those unsure

One of those "once in a decade" kind of games that really challenges usual conventions. Spooky without being full horror. Fun card mechanics without getting too crunchy. Unique puzzles and exploration outside of the card game. I can't say much else without spoiling it, but be sure to put your main focus on the puzzles around the cabin....This game is "transcendent".

This is Daniel Mullins at his PEAK! 
If you have played any of Daniel Mullins' GameJam games, you'll probably be familiar with like 1/10th of this whole concept. If you have played the following games: Magic, Yu Gi oh, Hearthstone, and The Pokemon Trading Card Game; you'll see a lot of references and tributes to those game even within the game mechanics shown. In otherwords: you'll be at home.

Inscryption is not afraid to break walls to a point where YOU the PLAYER can break the 4th wall yourself... ok kind of.. look its hard to explain everything that goes on in the room but 20$ will give you enough to keep you searching for clues so you can understand what I mean. Once you get even more curious, the game unfolds itself to where things get crazy. why would I put it like that?... well if you were to make it to the credits a mode is unlocked that TRULY fits the Roguelike genre... but then it gives a little more info that may.. ok if you beat the extra mode, just watch MattPatt's video explaining the secrets of the game itself. 
No? you don't want to? you want to solve this whole cracked mystery yourself? well good luck! I hope you like going outside!

Daniel Mullins created a Masterpiece that keeps breaking so many boundaries of Game dev relations with the player. Hell, after I finished streamed Inscryption I went back for more. Learned something new every time I came back.

Worth the $$
Worth the Time

A story-rich roguelite deckbuilder with point-and-click elements that's not afraid to go left. Go in blind. Stop reading reviews and buy it.

Inscryption should serve as a golden standard for how games should be structured. Not so short that it feels like a tech demo and not so long that it feels like a chore to play. Every single moment in this game felt deliberate and meaningful, seasoned with little secrets and puzzles that rewarded curiosity.
Being familiar with the dev's previous works, I expected some level of experimental genre breaking, but I was a little disappointed to find out that the most heavily marketed part of the game was only a small part of the game, as it felt the most engaging and fleshed out. While the rest of the game makes sense on a conceptual level, the gameplay and immersion took a hit afterwards. Fortunately there is a game mode that entirely focuses on the first part, but it's a shame that it wasn't the main focus of the story mode.
8.5/10

In the world of digital card games, "Inscryption" emerges as a dark horse, blending deck-building mechanics with an eerie narrative that grips you from the outset. Created by Daniel Mullins Games, this indie title transcends traditional genre boundaries by infusing psychological horror into a roguelike card adventure, resulting in a truly unique gaming experience.

At first glance, "Inscryption" appears to be a simple card game, but as the layers peel away, it reveals complex strategies and a deep, mysterious lore. The gameplay is ingeniously designed, constantly introducing new mechanics and challenges that keep you on your toes. With each playthrough, the game evolves, unveiling new secrets and narrative twists that entice you to dive deeper into its shadowy world.

The atmospheric graphics and sound design are standout features, perfectly complementing the unsettling tone of the game. The visuals are a blend of rustic and digital aesthetics, while the soundscapes envelop you in an immersive experience that's as haunting as it is engaging.

"Inscryption" is not just a game; it's a journey through a narrative that's as compelling as the gameplay itself. The story is rich with allegory and symbolism, prompting players to ponder the implications long after the screen goes dark.

In conclusion, "Inscryption" is a masterclass in indie game development. It's a bold, innovative adventure that's bound to enthrall card game enthusiasts and horror aficionados alike. If you're looking for a game that breaks the mold and challenges your perceptions, "Inscryption" is a must-play.

Rating: 9/10

Then, think of a card game that has none of the content from the first great roguelike, occasions where you just lose due to bad luck, repetitive starts, and having to redo several battles each and every time you lose. That's Inscryption. Try to beat the first act in less than 2 hours so you can refund it. After that, the game isn't worth playing.

Inscryption has an amazing campaign. The game balances fun gameplay, bold aesthetics, and an interesting story extremely well. There's a reason people say to avoid spoilers for this game. 

But even beyond the campaign, the roguelike mode (Kaycee's Mod) is incredible. I finished the campaign and decided to check it out, and was shocked by how much more content there is after the incredible story. The campaign alone would justify the price tag, so I didn't expect to play Kaycee's mod and keep unlocking things... new starter decks, new challenges (the last of which was the biggest surprise for me in this game), and new cards. This game is a must-play and probably my favorite of all time.

I like the game but to me the overall story isn't what makes it stand out, which i sort of expected after reading the comments about how great the story is so that's unfortunate. Idk I feel like I expected a bigger pay off to what was set up.

I'd still definitely recommend the game as I love the way it looks and the gameplay is great! But I think id have enjoyed it more if I had lower expectations. 

All in all a fun deckbuilder with puzzles and some fun surprises along the way

Inscryption, the game that utterly blew my mind. I wish I could talk about the experience with this game but I want to spoil absolutely nothing. I usually dive into games blindly anyways but I cannot stress this enough that the less you know about this game, the better the experience. The reviews speak for themselves, and as much as you might have the urge to quit or search something up, just keep pushing. I promise you, patience is rewarded. Only thing I will say is that you could search up how to solve certain puzzles but i'm only saying this as a last last resort and after you've spent many hours stuck on that one puzzle. The average play time is 12 hours so unless you're pushing 18 hours and still have not finished is when I'd probably look at a guide. And remember, this game is quite difficult and you will get frustrated but like all things in life, there is no joy without pain, think of it like a dark souls game. This is such a beautiful game and I truly believe it is a must have in everyone's library. I only wish I could erase my memories of this game to experience it again. 

(related to this from another reviewer so I wanted to add this in my own review too. Its the only problem I had with this game)
"- It‚Äôs almost too deep. I get the feeling that without joining the Discord, taking part in the ARGs and watching Youtube videos I will never really fully understand this game or at the very least see everything that it has to offer. I wish I had the time to delve into every little facet of the game and discover it all for myself but I don‚Äôt. And this makes me sad." - Sigmar's Sausage.

Without spoilers, this is a very well built card game meant to exercise your neurons with strategies and tactics that force you to think outside the box. Do you wanna doomstack a card? You can do that. Do you want to populate the board with spam? You can do that. The items are excellent battle aids without being so necessary you MUST have them. There are a LOT of ways to play a deck and the randomized nature of what you get makes it a new trip every time.

There's a story to this game. It's really good, kinda campy but in a really cute way that works super well. It's the kind of thing you can easily enjoy. The characters too, although I won't go too far into it.

There's also after-story content too. So I'd say the replayability is pretty good. So to reiterate, it's good. Buy it and enjoy it.

Daniel Mullins Games is mostly known for horror-themed metafictional elements in its games, and that's a very strong component in this title as well. What sets Inscryption apart is that, on top of narrative shenanigans, the core card battling gameplay loop is pretty darn good. There aren't many deck archetypes (take your pick of midrange or aggro), but there are so many interesting mechanics and resources that can be bent in fun ways. That solid gameplay combined with metafiction framing and a hefty amount of polish leads to a truly intoxicating introduction. The back half of Inscryption is less stunning, but the strong metafictional twists help keep the gameplay fresh and the narrative intriguing. This is a very easy game to recommend to anyone interested in deckbuilders, horror, or truly novel experiences.

This game has two major aspects to it that are both very well made. If you've played previous Daniel Mullins Games titles, you'll likely have an idea of if you'll enjoy the narrative part of the game, but in case you haven't, it's a type of story where the less you know, the better. Do note that there are some fairly creepy elements to it, so if you don't like scary stories, that's going to make it harder to enjoy this one.

As for the gameplay, it is a fairly competent roguelike deckbuilder / cardgame.
Compared to Pony Island you can tell that the developer has improved a lot in both gameplay (I found Pony Island to be a bit slow and easy in gameplay) and narrative (less repeated dialogue in this one, plus a more interesting story overall).

There's a lot to talk about with this game, but the more you know the less novel the experience will be. So if you like your narrative with a bit of meta-narrative and also enjoy cardgames, especially roguelike deckbuilder style cardgames, and you don't mind some darker themes then this'll probably be great for you.

It is an amazing game that makes you feel like you are in the game and the Kaycee's Mod beta is a really fun thing to do after you have finished the game. I can't give this game enough praise, and if you are on the fence on buying it or not, I think it is definitely worth the 20$.

Absolutely phenomenal game. 10/10 in my opinion. Story elements just kept throwing twist after twist. When you think you're done with the game, you're not. 

Without spoiling anything, the ending did leave some questions opened, but then a new mode unlocks after beating the game. Playing this mode to completion fills in most of those questions through journal logs. 

With the constant bad, glitchy, unoptimized AAA games releasing every year, with insane price increases and DLC, it's so wonderful to see a solid, FULL release game, with no micro transactions. I have will over 100 hours of play, cause I ended up buying a physical for PS5 and playing fully through there as well.

If you're into card games like Yu-Gi-Oh and Magic the Gathering, this will be another that will get you addicted. The indie movie cutscenes were well done and really gave a creepy vibe, making me more invested on what was going to happen next. It was my favorite game of last year (yes, I know it's been out longer, but I didn't play or know anything about it until last year).

I highly recommend this game, even at full price. It's definitely worth your time and money.

after 10 hours i would definitely recommend this game but with a huge sign that says ready to die. lets go by acts
ACT 1
ACT 1 is where your usual card deck builder game starts, and its pretty fun. theres also puzzles that are hinted at by the living cards which gives you cards/items in your play. its very well designed, each icon on the map is a different event and you go through them to get to the boss, and beat it for the next area. if you havent died and still have two candles lit in said area, leshy will give you a free smoke card which can be easily sacrificed for other cards... an upgrade to the smoke card even makes the smoke and actual useful attacking card which is amazing! each boss is unique and has different weaknesses. this part of the game can be summed up in one word and it is experimentation. combine dupe cards for broken cards, add sigils onto already OP cards and so on. leshy is cheating already so why not you cheat also? my only complaint about this act is the over reliance on the permadeath mechanic. you HAVE to die a few times before getting to the next area, i wouldnt mind this because if you die, you are able to create a deathcard. a death card is a card where you choose its own stats so if you had OP cards in your deck before, theres a chance you could make another OP card. my complain with the permadeath mechanic is the demoralizing rubberbanding. you CANNOT win on your first try. the game will throw unfair fights to you so that you will die. its possible to overcome but for newer players, its very demoralizing and could lead to abandoning the game. i definitely recommend playing it through, the rewarding finish is worth it! 
ACT 2
ACT 2 is simply AMAZING. i was in awe about what david mullins did with this part. act 2 plays like an old SNES RPG. you have an overworld and in the overworld theres 4 different locations you can explore with 4 different inscryption scrybes. at first you can only beat leshy or the necromancer witch and each of those scrybe areas you will be challenged by the people there and solving puzzles. from taking pictures to fighting skeletons and writing obituaries on them. the P03 area and the magician area is also filled with fun characters and good fights. the cards play a bit different here too. at the start of the game, you will be able to choose cards decks you will main. there are 4 card decks which are robot, necromancer, animals and mages. instead of getting cards from a trader, you get cards from card packs. each enemy you fight will give you one or two card packs which could give you up to 5 cards. these cards also work with the 4 main decks of act 2. robot deck with batteries, mage deck with something, leshys deck with squirrels and necromancer deck with bones. you also make your own decks! you can have a hybrid of leshys and nercomancer decks to create an amazing deck for every enemy or try something different with mage decks or robot decks. this part of the game can be summed up in one word which is FUN. this part of the game wasnt frustrating and the abundance of card packs let players choose there ways to fight. this part of the game also doesnt rely too much on RNG. even if it you have a bad hand, you could always reroll with a nice clover. its very welcoming and doesnt put a toll on the player. now to the weakest part of the game
ACT 3 
ACT 3 has a very interesting premise. after being glitched out by P03, he now takes over the board. you will travel in botopia on the game board and as always, beat the bosses and do the great trancendence. i havent finished this part, but it definitely feels the weakest. it relies a LOT of RNG and battery recharges. you only get a battery per turn and most damaging cards use around 2 - 4 batteries so at one point, you HAVE to tank damage and you wont know whats coming. coming off of act 2's very nice rerolling mechanic, this one definitely feels the most unfair out of them all. sometimes you cant even move and you will just die, its insane. i dont like this part but there are some stuff i kind of like. i like botopia, its a nice setting. the dark factory also gives a very good atmosphere to this act and the money mechanic is very cool! theres a hub centre and a shop where you can buy upgrades using money. unlike previous acts where money/teeth are basically useless, this act encourages you to spend tons of your money. personally, i think this part is fine but theres probably a few ways to make it more welcoming like act 2 with a reroll mechanic, faster battery recharges (if your deck has a ton of 2 - 4 battery cost cards) and less unfair fights. 
OVERALL (so far)
this game is very good, sometimes its demoralizing but most of the times its very fun and encourages experimentation. the story is also very good and i liked the FMV style sequence every few bosses or so that tells the story of the character were playing as, which is a dude whos playing the inscryption game. i like this game, id recommend it to everybody whos looking for a fun card game.

INSCRYPTION is a horror game where the main mechanic of gameplay is trying to beat the man across the table, Leshy, in an odd card game and it is absolutely amazing.

I'm not big on card games, I think they're enjoyable & fun but they're not my favorite and I don't play them very often, so when I grabbed Inscryption I was a little bit mixed on what I expected, and I was pleasantly surprised. The card game you play is very fun & just makes you want to win, and failure only pushes you to win even more.

Inscryption is very eerie and mysterious, you get dropped in with not much context but trust me, there is some story & lore here, it is extremely interesting and makes you want to learn more about what this game truly is, and it's origins. This game truly is more than what you see on the store page, much much more.

If you're familiar with the dev, you'll prob expect genre switching throughout.  If you don't know what to expect, you might feel bait-and-switched when you're suddenly playing a 90's era Game Boy style RPG in the middle of this.  This was the first game of his that I ever played, so I was expecting the whole thing to be like the first section.  Unfortunately that's the best section, and if that was the only section it'd be a great game, so I'm going to have to still call it a great game.  The other 3 sections are still okay, they're just not nearly as good.   The drop in strategy is actually very severe too until Kaycee's Mod, when the game's story is already over.  That's not so bad though, b/c the story will have you rushing through sections 2-4 out of curiosity, you might not even realize how bad the gameplay nosedived.  Those sections are short anyway.  The story also makes it worthwhile, which you could guess if you played Pony Island or the Hex.

Few games have blown my mind more than this one did.  Really only The Witness was more mindblowing, so I definitely undersold it here.  It's been a while since I played, but I was thinking about it while playing lesser games recently.

Holy Moley! I just finished my first play-through of the game, and phew, what a ride! I highly recommend this game! This game is a masterclass in game design, Daniel Mullins has put himself on the map with this one!

What I loved about this game was the fusion/synthesis of multiple games: DnD dungeon master style progression, escape room puzzles, the deck building and of course the deck battling. I loved the story that unfolds as you progress through the game. I loved the themes that the game explored of horror, card games, gamer culture, story-telling, and even to a degree existence itself. 

What I hated about this game: 
Now that I have completed my first run through, I wish there was more to explore and play! I otherwise have zero negative comments about the game.

Worth every dollar! Big thanks to Daniel Mullins for publishing this creative work!

Inscryption is a gem among games, captivating from the start and impossible to put down. Its blend of card-based strategy, dark storytelling, and puzzle elements is executed with such brilliance that it stands out as a pinnacle of indie gaming. The way the narrative unfolds within the gameplay not only keeps you hooked but leaves you craving more with its innovative twists and turns.

The recent additions to the game only serve to deepen the intrigue and challenge, proving that the developers are committed to enriching the player's experience. While I find myself wishing for even more content, it's a testament to the game's allure and the desire it sparks to dive deeper into its mysteries.

[b] Gameplay [/b] is flawless, offering a solid 10/10 for its engaging mechanics and depth.

[b] The story [/b] is compelling, meriting a 9/10 for its originality and the way it seamlessly integrates with the gameplay.

[b] Graphics [/b] are stylistically fitting, scoring an 8/10, enhancing the atmosphere without overshadowing the game's other elements.

[b] Atmosphere [/b] is unparalleled, a perfect 10/10, creating an immersive world that's both eerie and enthralling.

Overall, I'd rate Inscryption a solid 9/10. It's a rare find that combines all elements of great game design into one cohesive and unforgettable experience. For those yearning for a game that marries story, strategy, and suspense, Inscryption is a must-play.

Inscryption is one of the most immersive games I have ever played. It does a lot of different things that break the normal "rules" of gaming in order to draw the player in. One simple example that also presents in other games is the title/settings screen being incorporated into the game. Instead of a blue transparent ui box popping up when you press escape, it is part of the lore of the game itself so that immersion is not broken. Inscryption does this on many occasions so much so that the rules of the game and reality are blended which lends to a more entertaining game and story.

The story itself is very interesting and falls in line with other Daniel Mullins' games. It is more interesting to go in blind with no preconceptions towards what is or could be going on. Initially, the game presents itself as a simple card game, yet as it continues it is obvious that something strange is happening.

One of the strongest points of Inscryption is the card game. I'd say Inscryption is a story first and a card game second. Unfortunately this means there really isn't enough of gameplay to be had. There is a good amount, but nothing close to other titles that solely focus on gameplay. I'd love to see a Slay the Spire inspired Inscryption spinoff that adds more card game elements with longer fights and increased complexity. The game still stands as a unique experience by itself. Highly recommend if you like card games, piecing together stories and spooky atmosphere.

[h1]ü§î Disclaimer / Introduction ü§î[/h1]
Inscryption disappointed me 1stly because I had relatively high expectations about it after reading many times that we should play it knowing nothing about it.

Actually, I don't think knowing in advance what it is about changes a lot the experience so this review will contain important [b][i]spoilers[/i][/b], but I won't get into any detail of the surprises so you'll still have fun playing the game if it's your cup of tea. :-)

[h1]üßê My Opinion üßê[/h1]
So the game is articulated in 3 chapters. The 1st one is by far the best because of its incredible atmosphere: we're trapped in a cabin in the woods, forced to play a card game with a mysterious character, and we don't understand much about what's going on exactly.

After that, it's kinda a downhill experience. First, the card game isn't great; we're forced to lose on several occasions to trigger some events, which is ok-ish, but then once this is done, we're left with games whose results mostly depend on luck: you have 8~10 cards in your deck, but start each game with only 4 chosen randomly; usually, not all your cards have the same strength, so you can start with 4 cards letting you win in 1 or 2 turns, or the opposite, losing in 1 or 2 turns.

This was very painful, so I save-scummed (by manually copying the file on the HD), so I could reach the end of the 1st chapter without too many tries.

Once done, you get to see some videos explaining the story a bit.

Then in Chapter 2, you get to play an 8-bit version of the game; the deck building this time makes a bit more sense, but you quickly get indestructible as the strategy overall is pretty basic for a hardcore gamer like myself.

This 2nd chapter is a bit long and gets somewhat tedious and repetitive.

Once you beat it, you get more videos to watch to discover the story, and then you come back to something relatively similar to the 1st chapter, but again with a better deck building, which leads again to the same issue: too easy & repetitive.

And then it's done, but it feels incomplete and kinda dumb. To understand what was missing, I had to read this: https://www.gamespot.com/articles/inscryption-ending-explained-arg-secrets-and-whats-going-on-in-the-story/1100-6497568/ . TL/DR: there's an Alternate reality game (ARG) that will lead you to the real ending: an unlisted video on YouTube (it felt very strange to read the excited comments under this video). It's still very rough and kinda dull, but at least you get the complete story.

So all in all, I didn't have much fun playing Inscryption, both on the core gameplay (the card game) and the obscure story & story-telling.

Thus said, the game is obviously well crafted for what it is and its author poured his heart into it.

It took me a bit more than 15 hours to beat the game.

[h1]üíñ Pros üíñ[/h1]
- Unique atmosphere in the 1st chapter, full of mystery
- Some quirks & well-thought weird things
- The ending feels tragic (if you forget how dumb is the premise, or if you really don't know how computers work)

[h1]üíÄ Cons üíÄ[/h1]
- No difficulty level: for hardcore gamers, it's 95% too easy, and for casual gamers, it might be a lot to take
- In the 1st chapter, the card game is too much luck-based
- In the next chapters, the card game seriously lacks strategic depth, as well as variations so it gets kinda repetitive
- The story-telling doesn't make much sense, as it mixes the points of view in an obfuscated manner
- The story is actually pretty basic once unobfuscated

If you're looking for a review on the game, this is the wrong place, but if you're looking for a great chocolate chip cookie recipe, you're in the right place!

-3 cups flour
-1 cup sugar
-1 cup light brown sugar
-2 eggs
-1 cup salted butter, softened
-1 teaspoon salt
-2 teaspoons vanilla extract
-1 teaspoon baking soda
-¬Ω teaspoon baking powder
-2 cups chocolate chips

1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees.
2. Mix together flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda in a medium bowl and set aside.
3. In a large bowl, mix butter and sugars until combined.
4. Beat eggs and vanilla into the large bowl for 1 minute.
5. Mix dry ingredients into the large bowl.
6. Add in chocolate chips.
7. Roll cookie dough into balls and place on cooking sheets (make sure they have parchment paper, oil, or some other non-stick substitute on them to prevent the cookies from sticking).
8. Bake in the oven for 8-10 minutes.
9. Take cookies out and, after sitting for a few minutes, transfer them to a cooling rack.
10. Enjoy your delicious cookies!

As a huge fan of both puzzle games and CCG's I really wanted to like Inscryption. It seemed like the perfect game from the store page. A roguelite CCG that was also a puzzle room? A dark mysterious story and tone? What's not to love? After playing through the entirety of the story mode as well reaching level 12 and doing the optional boss of Kaycees mod, however, there is unfortunately a lot not to love about inscryption, with my personal problems mostly having to do with the difficulty and the narrative. 

My difficulty problem is that the game is too easy, both in the puzzle sections and the card game sections in the story portion of the game. The first section of the game, the only truly rogue like portion of the campaign, is easily beatable in your first 4 or 5 runs and 2-3 hours. The other sections of the game are even easier, and each took me an hour or two at most. The CCG sections are very easy to break, with turn one kills being very easy to achieve in most stages of the game. As for the puzzles, answers either directly given to you, or solutions were so simple I was able to accidentally brute force them while trying to figure out the rules to the puzzle in question. 

Kaycees mod is a supposedly better balanced rogulike mode available after completing the story, sort of like NG+. It has slightly better difficulty, with adjustable difficulty settings and fewer puzzles. In this mode however, the game is hurt by aesthetic choices made for the story mode, with the first person, point and click controls that were made to be immersive and creepy in the story mode becoming constrictive and awkward once you have to do many runs in quick succession, with many of the puzzle elements they were designed to support removed. Kaycees mod is also, unfortunately, still very unbalanced. Where the base game rogue-like portion could be beaten easily by creating an unstoppable boss monster with the custom card mechanics, the optimal way to beat Kaycees mod is to beeline for one of Inscryptions many infinite combos then click a lot to find a victory. These combos are arguably even easier to find and enable in Kaycees mod, with new cards that seem designed to support uninteractive, combo heavy gameplay.

If the game was just easy, I wouldn't have a problem with it. I've played walking sims before with little to no challenge and have enjoyed them, but without going into spoilers, a significant part of inscriptions narrative and tone hinges around you being an underdog, trapped in some dire circumstance at the whims of an all powerful being. Unfortunately the game is so easy that you never feel that way, you're almost always bulldozing through encounters, only facing challenge when the game actively cheats, or changes the rules of the game fundamentally in a way you haven't encountered yet. You feel more like you're kicking a puppy than engaging in a battle of wits against a dark mastermind. The game also gets very meta, and without spoilers it gets meta in a way that I personally didn't like, I found it very intrusive and uncomfortable in a way that was probably intentional, but wasn't fun in any way shape or form.

To this review I will add a caveat. I've been avoiding spoilers in this review because I played Inscryption partially spoiled, and I think this may have soured my game-play experience somewhat. Inscryption's story is very meta, and relies heavily on creepy-pasta aesthetics and shocking twists for it's impact. Even knowing a rough outline of the game before jumping in was enough to suck all of the interest out of the genuinely engaging story decisions this game made, and ideas it explored. Unable to engage with the story, my focus was drawn much more to the game-play, which I disliked for the decidedly subjective, difficulty reasons mentioned earlier. The game-play didn't really hit it's stride for me until Kaycees mod, 10+ hours into a game I found myself struggling to enjoy. Even then, Kaycees mod can be made a tedious experience by design decisions made for to support the atmosphere of the main story mode, and while discovering infinite combos and turn one kill interactions can be fun, once you've found them that's it, your roguelike experience is now finding the easiest ways to execute your fastest infinite.

Given the plethora of other positive reviews for this game it is very likely you will like Inscryption. It does some genuinely clever things with narrative and genre and despite my complaints has solid core card gameplay. If you haven't been spoiled on the story and the game sounds interesting you should probably give it as shot. My negative recommendation is very personal. I'm not that in to creepy pasta as a genre, I don't particularly like meta fiction, and I am a puzzle game and CCG fiend. I found this game easy after spending thousands of hours on MTG. Gwent, Hearthstone and LOR, and played it immediately after playing The Witness, a very hard puzzle game which I likely subconsciously compared it to. If any of that sounds like you, I'd wait for mega sale.

Replaying this game made me remember why it's one of my favourites. The game does peak in the first chapter, as the immersion of it all just draws you in deeper to uncover what is going on within Inscryption. And of course, Leshy as a storyteller of sorts, with the low rumble each time he speaks, his eyes glowing in the darkness, only for him to wear a mask and give off a completely different energy in the boss fights, it's simply phenomenal.
The rest of the game is still fantastic in many ways, especially gameplay wise. And the visual quality of the first chapter can still be seen in the third. I especially love the personality and design of the game's real antagonist [spoiler](P03)[/spoiler].
And of course, the ending is an absolute spectacle. [spoiler]Lore stuff aside, the way it all crumbles apart is awesome. The return to Leshy's cabin is emotional, making you realise he never really was an antagonist. My only complaint with the whole game really is that the lore tape parts are a bit obnoxious, and I wish Leshy's cabin were the last thing you visited before it all deletes, rather than you ending with Magnificus.[/spoiler]
Anyways, play this game. You won't regret it.
EDIT: I've now also finished Kaycee's Mod, which is basically the post-game content which offers a more challenging experience in Leshy's cabin. This mode is great fun and even has an ending of its own that leaves you feeling satisfied with the whole experience. 10/10 game.

[h1] Inscryption - 2024 review [/h1]

I'll keep this premise short, unlike I usually do: I have never been so engaged by a video game before. For what seems to be a pretty straightforward title, you'll discover a story deeper than you could ever imagine. I'll be breaking down everything that makes this game so great, even though it also has its minor downsides.

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*] For starters, just like I mentioned nearly two lines ago, I think this is one (if not [i] the one[/i]) of the best story I've experienced in my life. Not just in video games. EVER. The reason why it's so good is because you'll never expect this kind of effort from a storytelling perspective for a card battler. I cannot explain anything without spoiling something, the game as a whole is a spoiler, so you'll have to trust me on this one. DO NOT GO ONLINE TO SPOIL YOURSELF! Inscryption cannot be experienced twice. Once you know what happens, you'll lose interest.
[*] The overall audiovisual characteristics of the game are off the charts. A retro-like game never appealed me so much from a video perspective. The art style is creepy and efficient, there's borderline horrific elements, I felt pressured into playing certain cards on occasion, etc. The sound effects and the soundtrack that accompanies it all is just the cherry on top. You'll feel immersed on a whole new level.
[*] The AI is tough, but fair. Expect to die a lot and restart a lot. It sounds a lot more frustrating than it actually is, because when you die, you'll get a chance to dive deeper into the story and discover new aspects the game has to offer.
[*] The performances are great, and pretty much any rig, even low-end, can run this game without expecting serious issues. It's a very stable game, and I've never encountered a bug once.
[*] Just like I said earlier, I'm usually not a fan of card battlers, but this one is done right. You start off very simple but add a lot of depth to your deckbuilding experience, and the game transitions those new elements very smoothly. You end up with a lot of options without feeling overwhelmed, which I particularly enjoyed.
[*] It took me around 15 hours to finish the main campaign, without touching the extras or replaying it. I've found that to be the perfect length to keep me intrigued while not cutting it too short nor dragging it for too long. [/list]

[b] Neutrals [/b]
[list]
[*] It can get a tiny bit repetitive, especially depending your learning curve. Once you finish the game, you can access a lot of extra content, and it took me a while to get to it because I got burned out of the gameplay after finishing the campaign. I recently got back to it, and I thoroughly enjoyed fully completing it. I've put this point in [i]Neutrals[/i] because I think the repetitiveness comes after completing the campaign, which is where most people will stop playing it. [/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] A major downside of this game is that, well, it starts off too perfect. I won't explain too much to avoid any spoilers, but the first couple hours into the game are so enjoyable that when you reach a certain point, you'll feel a little slacking off. This doesn't mean this certain part of the game isn't good, on the contrary, I still liked it, but I was kind of disappointed of what it was turning into compared to the beginning. Thankfully, the endgame makes up for it, so it isn't a downward slope from the beginning to the end.
[*] A more specific complaint is that the game cannot be experienced twice. Your first time is unique. So if you've been spoiled in any way, or if you've watched a gameplay on YouTube to find out what the hype is all about, you probably know at this point that you won't enjoy it as much as someone who goes in completely blind. [/list]

[b] TL;DR [/b]
If this game interests you the slightest, buy it. You won't regret it, even at full price. I cannot say it is a perfect game, but I assure you that it comes close for most. You don't need to enjoy card battlers, roguelikes or deckbuilders to have fun. You only need to crave a rich story from where you expect it the less to be. Shout out to the solo developer behind this masterpiece!

Sadly I can't recommend this game, because I feel scammed. Seems like I'm one of those "that didn't get it". What I thought I bought was what I could see in the videos and pictures of the shop page and what I'd seen on YouTube before. Apparently, this was only "act 1" after which the style completely changed. I didn't buy this game for its visuals alone, but this mix of 3D-puzzle and cardbattler with its, let's call it forked minimap was what I thought this game would be to the end. But act 2 changed the artstyle, went from 3D to 2D/isometric, you could run around where ever you want... act 3 brought back some of the good things from act 1. But still, act 2 and act 3 didn't feel enjoyable at all. I quit and uninstalled the game, when I knew what was happening. After a long time I picked it back up again to restart the game, so I could simply play act 1 again. To my surprise the "restart" began at act 2 all the time. Still, I fought through act 2 and 3 which took a lot of unfullfilling hours. More than I thought. In the end I didn't care for the story anymore. Then, finally, I got to the end and unlocked "Kayceys Mod" which itself was everything I thought the game itself would be. Roguelite, 3D puzzle, cardbattler, forked minimap (like act 1, not act 3) and so on. But act 2 and 3 ruined the game for me. I can't enjoy this game anymore, not even the "mod" which makes me sad, because it was completely unnecessary. If only there was something on the storepage showing that most of the game isn't actually anything like act 1. If you scroll all the way through the media in the store page, there is a video with a 2 second clip showing something other than act 1. Out of 4 minutes of video and half a dozen pictures. Not only the artstyle, but the gameplay itself changed so drastically, that not showing this on the storepage this isn't even "preventing spoilers" anymore, but feels like straight out lying. That is a behavior I do not condone.
If the dev was more honest regarding what this game was like, I whouldn't have bought it, but would understand people praising it because of its artistic value.
If the dev had kept the content of the game limited to "Kayceys Mod" that whould have been way better for me and it would have been a garantied "recommended" from me.
But this... is just disappointing.

There's a lot going on with this game. More than is apparent at first. I appreciate that there is a narrative that is usually lacking from even the best deck-building games. Lots of very cool stylistic choices. If you've ever played a card game and were the one person trying to get the crazy combo to go off, this is the game for you. Similarly, if you want something that's the epitome of "easy to learn, hard to master" in card game form, this is it. INSCRYPTION is a game packed to the brim with secrets, and it's always a blast learning something new. 10/10

Inscryption is a masterfully crafted game that defies traditional gaming conventions. Its blend of card-based gameplay with psychological horror elements creates a truly unique and gripping experience. The game's narrative is deeply engaging, keeping players on the edge of their seats as they unravel its mysterious and dark storyline. The clever integration of puzzle mechanics adds another layer of depth, making each playthrough a rewarding challenge. With its innovative approach and captivating storytelling, Inscryption is a must-play for anyone seeking a truly memorable gaming experience.

This game is just... wow, I've never experienced something like this in gaming, and to think it came from a card game? 

Act 1 used to be my favorite, I mean it had it all. It was charming, it looked great, it made me question everything in the game and I loved the experience personally.

Act 2, however, personally took the rating down a lot for me. It took the fun and joy from Act 1 and ruined it by changing the clever mechanics the first act had and making you play what seemed like a completely different game. It was not fun, and I was almost ready to quit altogether, but I stuck through, and I don't regret it.

Act 3, without giving any spoilers, is like Act 1, but with new sigils and new mechanics that, honestly, made me like it a lot. I'd go as far as to say I personally enjoyed it as much, if not more than Act 1. I don't know if others feel this way, but I do. I enjoyed it a lot.

Inscryption was definitely worth the money I paid for it. It was a great experience, and I look forward to playing again and again in the future.

Things I liked about it.  Original, different, refreshing.  Things I didn't like about it.  Bad, if original, graphics - pixellated, card game could be more fleshed out and have more to do.  Repetitive, I would rather have seen more levels/more bosses and an option to continue after each stage (easy mode maybe) and and maybe more lives, it's pretty difficult at the end. Got to the final boss numerous times but he kept getting me on the last candle. I simply ran out of patience to play more as no real sense of progression and if you lose you have to go through the entire 3 stages again....this is too annoying for me.  Overall this is a $3-$5 game at most. Not worth full price, but probably recommend in a sale if you like card games.  In short, maybe worth a look but check you tube to see if you might like it.

I do think this game is much better if you go into it blind, so as a warning this review does have spoilers about the general layout of the game, but not much specifics. For a general review, I'd give this game 3/5: fun but dragged down by the middle of the game. Don't read ahead if you wanna go in blind.



The game is kinda split up into 5 acts(including the bonus content): Each act completely shifts the game. I'll try to explain the ups and downs of each act then give a general review of the game given that.

Act 1(first 3-8 hours or so)
Act 1 is the experience advertised on the store screen and is a very fleshed out deck builder rogue-lite. Though it can start a little bit slow(barely) it's overall really enjoyable and kept me entertained for most of it. 

Act 2(follow up 1-2 hours or so)
At first act 2 felt really crazy however I quickly realized how much worse it was from act 1. All of the intensity and strategy from act 1 was just kinda thrown out a window. All the rogue-lite elements were also gone. It may not seem like that big of a deal since it was only a few hours, but I dreaded this act and was just kinda infuriated with how boring it felt. I think I would've appreciated this act more if it was after act 3 as more of a optional bonus section, but throughout all of act 2 I was just in a rush to finish this section to get to the next "fun" section.

Act 3(follow up 4-6 hours or so)
When I first got into act 3 I was pretty hyped at first, but my excitement died quick. Act 3 was more similar to act 1, but instead of being a rogue-lite deck builder it was a campaign esc card builder: It was better than act. On top of that, the way you got out cards in this act was just flat out boring. Act 3 turned your side deck from a useful pile of fuel(essentially) to a worthless pile of garbage that doesn't do anything. The part that annoys me about this is that later in this act they introduce 2 ways to make the side deck actually somewhat useful, but by the time they do this you only have an hour or 2 left of the act. Both of these upgrades are awesome, but they introduce new mechanics way to late. Since this isn't a rogue-lite anymore you can't build around the mechanics of these upgrades very much. I think this act did have some awesome mechanics though. The boss fights weren't difficult, but they had really interesting mechanics(still not enough to compensate for the rest the act). If the late act upgrades were always there and it kept the rogue-lite elements of act 1 I think I would've really enjoyed act 3, but I was just really disappointed in this act.

Act 4(follow up 30 minutes or so)(barely an act)
This act was very cool and brief, but kinda made me more disappointed. Act 2 introduced the potential for four separate proper acts(2 of which were done in act 1 and act 3). Act 4 disappointed me because the final 2 potential acts were just kinda jammed in act 4 very briefly.

Act 5(bonus content kinda)(as long as you like or about 10+ hours for 100% achievements)
Act 5 is this games redemption. Act 5 simply takes the strongest part of the game(act 1) and revamps it to be much more re-playable. 

Overall I do still think this game is worth it just for acts 1 and 5(and because doing all the achievements is pretty fun), but wow this game disappointed me many times. The most annoying part about this game for me is that I would've enjoyed acts 2 & 3 if they were just slightly revamped. It's cool to have a game that's so willing to switch it up like this one, but it just wasn't done that well

One of the most BEAUTIFULLY crafted games I've ever played. Very few games have made me throw down my headset and walk away from my desk because of a big story twist/reveal, and this game made me do just that multiple times. The characters are clever, and they feel so real, which is even further backed up by the incredible story behind the game. I could gush about this game for hours, I love everything about it. The style, the gameplay, the storytelling, what's not to like? If you're a fan of strategy, horror, or just a cool story, you'll enjoy this game.
Inscryption is such a memorable game. Leshy's gamemaster shenanigans are incredibly clever, and it felt bittersweet when it was over.

I wanted to give an honest, simple review after finishing the story mode, but it was so much to take in that I had to play it twice, and now my mind is even more of a mess. The best way to describe this game is an abstract journey across the word, where a player will discover the truth and betrayal, while also consumed by addictive puzzles, primarily in the form of "a" card game. The later chapters are amazing and I'm seriously worried my computer has been corrupted... will I get shot in my own home after exposing the makers of this game to the media... I guess you'll never know so long as you just press the "new game" button. Right?

OH MY GOD, THE ONE GRIPE, AND I MEAN THE ONE GRIPE I HAVE WITH THIS GAME IS THAT IT ENDED TOO SOON, THIS GAME IS AMAZING AND I WANTED MORE! 

I usually dont care for long games because I dont think the longevity of a game determines if the game is deemed "good" but rather by what the game has to offer and how well crafted the game was made and holy hell is this game well made. This game is made for both seasonal Card players and people that don't play card games at all! it is so well crafted that a person like myself, someone that is not into card games, wanted more and more the longer I played. The story telling of this game is incredible and its aided by the characters in the game! The way how the game introduces new mechanics and then includes them right after you learned it, is so magnificent! [spoiler]Its so amazing how in the 2D section all play styles are combined while in the 3D is more catered to the scrybe and they add their own rules.[/spoiler] Even if you forget what something does, It included a QOL that can just remind you what it is by a simple click, so you wont need to worry about looking it up or spending time reading rules or anything! The way all these different genres of games blend together into one package is honestly so impressive and never in my life would I thought a game can blend this well and be so fun and addicting to play. The game has great atmosphere as well with the music and environment, which aids a lot to the story of the game [spoiler] I know a lot of people Enjoyed the first Act of the game more than the Third because Leshy is a great storyteller and role player at that! but I thought it was so genius on how P03 was a complete contrast! That was the whole point! He is a lifeless robot that is focused on min maxing the Game play of the card game and thinks storytelling is not important, the best way to see it is like if P03 was the big corporations making triple A games for money and Leshy was the Indie dev that actually cared about the presentation of their game. Even the music for that section matched the atmosphere of where you play (a lifeless factory) and the character you're up against (a lifeless robot)[/spoiler] By the time I was at the end and done with the game I said out loud "Thats it?" because I wanted so much more! It got me craving for more content and I Really hope Daniel Mullins makes DLC for this game, I dont even care if I have to pay for it, this game deserves every penny. [spoiler]Seriously! when I beat P03 I thought I was going to be able to go back to the islands and pick a new Scrybe! I was trying to get through it quick for that reason, I wanted to see the other 2 in the 3D setting! I thought it would play out something like the island expand a bit and you have to fight a few more new people in each region, then get a new scrybe into power and I was so dissapointed that it didnt happen, instead we got a teaser of what Grimora would of looked like as well as Magnificus, and I would of absoltuely enjoyed a Yu-Gi-Oh arena style with him. Not only that but the 2D section could of had so much more as well, there's a whole seperate way to play on that Act that I kept thinking of it as a stand alone game.[/spoiler]

Pure perfection (in my eyes at least)!

The Story is told in a really interesting way and i really love the creativity behind the whole story with it being told in both an ARG and sentient game way. The characters and world building that are done here are also really well mastered and had me really immersed. 

The Settings that you go through are well crafted and never made the game go stale from repetition. Each area you go through has its own personality and aesthetic that are as great as the last. 

Visually, its entrancing. Performance was perfectly fine with there being no bugs or glitches. Art Direction is phenomenal with it switching up its direction multiple times and all of it feeling really well designed and it being both distinct and connected at the same time. 

Sound and Audio are brilliant as well with the soundtrack always having this sense of eeriness and the audio being a perfect match for this environment. 

In terms of gameplay, it is pure addiction. The whole game is pretty much a deck building roguelike and its crafted so so well. I love all the mechanics that the game gives you when it comes to types of cards to even playing them on the deck which was done in a really smart way. There's also escape room element to the game which (while there not be that much of it) I really like what they've done with it and definitely added another layer to the game. 

Overall, Inscryption has so many elements that i love in gaming and is an experience i won't be forgetting anytime soon.

No spoilers, but what you'll see here is a ride.

Inscryption, a multi-level card game with depth, story telling, and fantastic visuals. 

Rating: 10/10

Summery: inscryption is a card game that takes place within its own world. With Luke being you in the story, you find yourself at a table apposing a strange figure on the other side. He lays out cards, a scale, and a bell. From there your journey with this masterpiece of a card game begins. One which is best enjoyed blindly.

Personal Notes: I have played through the game twice now, and both times were a blast. No game is like it, and it ranks on that special place in library among games such as Superliminal and Firewatch. It truly is a fantastic game, with a one of a kind unique visual take on card games. As well as a deep lore if you are into such. Plenty of Easter eggs to hunt for that are harder than most. There are sub reddits and plenty of YouTube channels to fall down the rabbit hole too. If you have any interest in cards, its super easy and does not take a high understanding of any other card games to enjoy. If card games are not really your thing do not let it discourage you from trying it. 

As a side note, doing voices for the characters makes it 10x better. Good luck challengers!

Amazing card game. Inscryption really shocked me with how deep it goes in terms of switching up the story and gameplay. I really wish we could have had more time up against Grimora as bone cards were some of my favorite during playtime. I also really appreciate how Inscryption feels like it has replay value, without leaning too hard into the roguelike aspects. 9/10 I wish there was a little more variety in bosses in Leshy's sessions, super fun game with an interesting story and ARG elements.

One of the most charming games I've played or even seen in a good while. And I'm not just talking about the unique and strange game play, I'm also talking about the art style and graphics of the game as well. How in Act 1 it's 3D but still pixelized, but in Act 2 it turns a classic top down 2D/Pixel style. And the decision to make characters have their own sounds when they talk adds a lot to the feel of the game. The game play itself is really fun and cool, I genuinely really liked how despite all 3 acts being card related, they switch things up entirely and you have to relearn how to do most things. And the way they executed *how* these card games and rules work is honestly amazing. Not to mention, combining a card game with the horror genre? and making it an ARG? I really hope to see more games *this* unique from these developers because it was a great experience. Oh, and the boss fights in act 3, some of the coolest mechanics I've ever seen in a game, one of them connects you to the internet and create your own card to send to another real player, and if they win with your card then you win, but you can also receive cards from others too; another boss makes you dig through your own computer files to find the biggest sized files you can and depending on how large it is, you do extra damage; and I could talk about the other two Uberbot bosses but I think I've made my point.

-Great soundtrack to listen to as you play, it really captures the mood of the game, especially the boss fights. (IThe "Scrybe of Magick" song is soooo good).
-The style and graphics of this game, as well as the character designs themselves is super charming to look at. (Despite the dude being a bit annoying, I really liked Po3. Also Lonely Wizbot best character 100/10 best boi).
-The game play itself has some of the coolest mechanics I've ever seen in a game, really shows how much thought and care the developers put into making this.

The story itself is a bit confusing. I get that it's suppose to be an ARG and you're suppose to figure it out and all - and that it's probably my fault for not understanding it completely - but I did get lost like halfway through, especially towards the end when somehow the game disc is sentient or something? There's nothing wrong with the story itself, maybe just the way it's presented. EDIT: I just found out this was an actual ARG where people had to find the Inscryption floppy disk irl, I just did a bunch of research on the puzzles and what people had to figure out to get the full story, I completely take what I said before this back because now i understand that it's suppose to be hard to understand on purpose. The developers really went all out with hiding secrets, they even hid stuff in past games that you have to play to decipher codes in this game.

All in all this is one of the cooler and more fun games I've played in years, can't really think of another that was - for the millionth time - this unique. I mean there's really no better words to describe this game besides unique. Thank you developers for this experience. 10/10.

This game gives a new definition to the word "roguelike." Yet it's also a continuation of an ever deepening story of mystery, horror, and video gaming itself. Right when you boot up the main menu and press "continue" in lieu of starting a new game (the option being denied to you... at first), you are immediately introduced to the nature of Inscryption as a subversion of even your most basic expectations. A game where the questions you'd normally ask no longer apply, where the story can only be deciphered by actively searching for it, where your perspective as a player (and perhaps YouTuber) is directly integrated into the character you play as and the gameplay you experience. 

Few games have the balance between showing you the ropes and refusing to hold your hand, and fewer still successfully make that a rewarding experience throughout the entirety of its content. This is also the first time I've ever encountered a game where I was invested in the story, couldn't fully make it out, then realized that that was because I was meant to play other games from the same developer without ever being told or clued in directly by the game itself; subtle hints and references to Pony Island and The Hex are included in such a way that both longtime fans and discovering newcomers can be pleasantly satisfied. 

Thank you to Daniel Mullins Games for absolutely sticking to the road less traveled by, and sharing a truly one of a kind game for all to enjoy. Can't wait for Pony Island 2: Panda Circus!

Pro's 

1. Interesting concept, especially Act 1. Really enjoyed the game mechanic concept, best part of the whole game.

2. Act 2 was a little less interesting than Act 1, but still kept the charm of the card battle mechanic.

3. With the added free DLC, the game has a bit more longevity due to replaying the Act 1 game mode.

4. Character designs were interesting and some of the meta concepts were fun. Overall I enjoyed the theme it was going for. 

5. Acts 1-3 are all pretty easy to beat even with the rouge-like mechanics and RNG. 

6. Game is able to be modded 


Con's

1. RNG can be a bit too punishing at times with the DLC. (obviously its a rouge-like to an extent but there are limits) even if you are not using the totems to increase difficulty, there will be many times you will just outright lose a fight due to bad RNG and since you can't quite build your deck in the typical sense, this can be a bit frustrating when you lose multiple runs in a row and you are just wanting to progress with unlocking more cards. 

2. Some cards are particularly not as helpful as others and feel like a waste of space (the ant cards for example, takes a lot to setup and good RNG to have a low card deck to get them on the field sooner. 
 
3. Too meta for its own good sometimes or doesn't quite land, mostly does though.

4. Act 3 was the a bit tedious game play wise and I think if you were not forced to have the color scheme as a dim blue, I wouldn't have minded nearly as much, but the other Acts had color variety and your eyes will miss that and get tired.

5. No way that I know of without mods to try and build a custom deck to use on more challenging runs.

Overall: A creative and fun game with a few flaws (some a bit more noticeable than others), but some of these "flaws" may be due to design choice and just are not for everyone, which is fine. Definitely worth playing all the way through. Looking forward to what the developer does next.

This game (or maybe it's just the host) practically tames you with a carrot and a stick: once you get a card, a totem or anything else that you naively think will make you unstoppable, the next fight won't give you a chance to stand for more than 2 rounds (and ofc you won't be getting your powerful card during that). Once humbled by the host's words of disappointment after another loss, the other time you get a modest praise and a "treat", or a new toy to play with. What the host gives, he'll take away from you again. If you're not cautious enough. I'm not a smart person and I tend to play Kaycee's mod when I wanna relax, so I'm well experienced in losing with a strong deck that is not supposed to lose. What a refreshing feeling. It is also very lovely that no guides will help you to get all the achievements: you may know the theory but as long as you suck at planning and analyzing, the gameplay won't let you further. That's why I barely google anything and always explore the game on my own.
I wish there was an actual board game but it would definitely not be meant to play alone.

I really like games by Daniel Mullins (even if Hex was a bit flawed gameplay wise).

Sadly, "Inscryption" is the worst possible kind of RNG card game you can find.

You can nurture your awesome card deck and creatures for 3 maps only to got the worst possible kind of hand you can be dealt with on a boss. 

And you won't even have a chance to play your awesome cards cause you'll be destroyed in three turns without any chances to pull something good out of the deck.

And the boss has two lives (with some ugly special when he loses one) and player suddenly got only one life (even though you really tried to conserve two lives for the whole run).

And this happens like three runs in a row.

Feels cheap and unfair.

I will be honest, I went into this expecting to not really like it because usually I am not a fan of turn deck builders, yet inscryption didn't just simply prove me wrong, it blew my best dreams out of the water, I am writing this review after having completed the game with all achievements unlocked and it is a testament that in my last run I saw a interaction that I didn't know exists before to how much love and polish is in this game. 

Not only are there countless of synergies and interactions that can easily break the game and lead to a winning run, the game takes the bold step forward to dare you to break it, leading to some of the most hilarious builds and synergies I have seen period. 
But this isn't the only shining aspect of this game, every one of the characters is charming and memorable, I wont spoil anything but some of the final moments of the game had me tearing up. I never thought that a medium could turn it's villain around in such a way that you go from hating them to deeply caring about them towards the end yet this game pulled it off, I recommend it to everyone who see's this review.

Game went from a frustrating, but still enjoyable deck building game to an ARG smashed together with a shitty 2D deck building "simulator", and ended with one of the worst downgrades in gameplay I have ever seen: It turned into what could only be described as a RNG based Groundhog Day videogame. This is not "integration of story and gameplay," this is sloppy game design.


The entire game is so confused that it cannot decide whether you have a skill or a luck issue. I do not want to die over and over and over and wait until I get a decent setup, I want to get good and learn from my mistakes if I lose. Getting curb-stomped because you're helpless to stop something that is not even in your control is NOT fun. Having the majority of your progress undone because you drew a useless hand while your opponent draws a god hand happen to you on a regular basis is frustrating.


The third act takes the cake for bad game design: Take that majority luck based gameplay, take that dying 100's of times until you get lucky, and you get act 3. You will die SO MANY TIMES without being able to do anything about it, and you will not even be able to remove shitty cards from your deck. There is no strategy, there is only blind luck. I sequence broke and got the 20/20 ouroborobot early, and I could NEVER draw it because my deck was filled with so much useless junk. I ended up uninstalling it after deciding it was one of the least enjoyable games I have played.

Spoiler in case you're still interested in how this garbage game ends: [spoiler] Remember how I said that the game turned into a shitty ARG? Well, if you didn't care for that part of the game and glossed right over it, you'll get an ending where your character gets smoked, and that corporate girl steals the game. It comes out of nowhere and you have no idea what is even happening unless you've played this developer's previous games before. It's so incredibly disappointing that you don't even know why this girl would choose to murder the MC in such an over the top fashion unless you've caught up with the entire story. [/spoiler]
The ending ends up being "What just happened? Why should I care?" and seemingly there for shock value alone.

Please spend your money on a deck building game that actually considers how much fun the player will have. You will get more enjoyment by literally bashing your skull against a brick-wall rather than figuratively in this case.
i cried, 9.5/10... it would be a 10/10 if they added a multiplayer feature

Great game, great OST, great gameplay. It's satisfying to play while also being hard enough to be a roguelike.

(Minor spoiler alert)

The game is divided into three different acts. Most of the negative review come from the second act being boring and annoying. While this is true to an extant, you get over it quickly. Act three is more of a challenge and is interesting enough, altho it isn't made for everyone. Both are more story driven than act 1 and can therefore feel a bit more boring to someone who came solely for the roguelike aspect of the game.

To those who only want to play the first act over and over without having to complete the other 2 acts, you can just press "Shift + M + K" in the menu. This will allow you to unlock a run based gamemode solely happening in act 1. I would still suggest finishing the game before doing so.

Overall, Inscryption is a great game that isn't suited for everyone, but is still pretty damn fun.

This game has so many cool ideas and somehow executes all of them extremely well. An interesting story with interesting characters all built on game systems that could've stood alone, which is proven true by the post-game "mod". A must play for deck-building fans, rouge-like fans and anyone curious about the mysteries the game holds.
Great card game, love the atmosphere.

As someone who has been playing video games for over 10 years and as someone who isn't the biggest fan of horror or psychological horror, I have to say that this is easily one of the greatest games i have ever played. The base game itself deserves to be in the hall of fame of gaming. Even then the amount of easter eggs, hidden secrets and lore is just incredible. The suspense, story telling, and mystery is beyond anything i have ever seen. The amount of times my mind was blown throughout the entire game is too many to count. On top of that, the base card game itself is surprisingly addicting and well thought out. I would recommend playing this game without any spoilers at all if you can. This game is an experience like no other. 10/10

A very fun card game. All the boss fights in each act have their own gimmick which allows for different strategies while using the same deck. The game has a mechanic where MOST of the time it will put your win-condition cards either in the middle of your deck or very back as to avoid steam-rolling through the whole thing by always drawing said card early. while this is an okay way to balance difficulty, and can sometimes be exciting to try and survive until you get your trump card, it is no lie to say that a lot of the time it is not fun as the game is and feels stacked against you. What could have been a feeling of a normal game with unlucky shuffling turns into knowing that the game purposefully **** you. But if that's a challenge that you don't mind, it really is a splendid card game.
A great game with lots of twists

Prior to buying, I read the comments for Inscryption and it said that the game is best experienced going in blind. So I did and yup, they were certainly correct, so I'm gonna do the same.

Firstly, the card game is alright. It evolves enough to keep it mostly interesting and I did enjoy it most of the time, but some parts of the game felt like a bit of a grind. As the card game is most of the gameplay loop, you'd think this would be a problem, but not really as that's the only negative thing I have to say about the game, as despite the gameplay feeling like a grind occasionally, I kept playing because the atmosphere and story were impeccable and I desperately wanted to know more. Thoroughly recommend this game. Like Outer Wilds and Stanley Parable before this, it's an indie game that came out of know where and blew my socks off. Hope you enjoy it too.

Def not what I thought I was signing up for but whoa, what a pleasant surprise. The core game is such a great/original idea but then the added "leveling" elements & twists is just amazing. I'm having a good time with it despite it having some elements I usually dislike in games so A+!
this game is so fucked up and that's what makes it so amazing

What initially drew me to this game was its unique and charming artistic style, as deckbuilder rouge likes weren't really my style of game, but Inscryption is a delightfully fun and intriguing game full of interesting lore and pretty fun game play. The base game is not insanely difficult but presents a fun challenge. I will say the first and final acts definitely hold up the strongest, not that acts 2 and 3 aren't good, the slight game play shift takes some adjusting to, and I'm so happy the devs added a challenge mod based in the first act.

I have never, ever played a game like Inscryption. It is unlike almost any other game I have played, not just because it's a roguelike card builder, a genre I'm not particularly into, but also what it is beneath all that. I recommend you don't read this review and just purchase the game for yourself, don't read anything about it just go in totally blind. Preserving that first time playthrough as one without any knowledge of the game is the best, so just pick up a copy and go to town. You might not think you love card games but I swear it's easy to understand and SUPER addictive. 

Okay. Don't read anymore. 





I've never thought to myself "What is this game" while playing something before. Don't get me wrong, similar things have been said while playing weirdo kinda stories like Death Stranding or Nier Automata, but when I say "What is this game" in relation to Inscryption, I genuinely did not understand what the game I was playing actually was within its own world. What you think Inscryption is, the card game in an abandoned cabin with a crazy man, is not actually the game. That's actually a recording of someone playing a game he found in the woods. You watch video clips of a real guy and watch as he descends into this mystery with you. When you find the ability to start a new game it then becomes a 2D, 8-bit NES style RPG. Then after that it returns to 3D but now you're stuck with a crazy robot in an abandoned factory. Inscryption refuses to be fully grasped, and I have never played anything quite like it. 
While I enjoyed Act 1's gameplay the most, the story it told throughout was undeniably so intriguing and fantastic. Alongside that, the real-world ARG and the inter-connectedness of this game with the creator's other works is staggering in it's planning and thoroughness. Finishing Inscyption the card game only ends the first act, and finishing Inscryption the video game is only the beginning of your own research into the crazy lore behind it all. 
This is, without a doubt, an indie masterpiece, a scarily well-constructed mystery, and just a badass card game. I genuinely cannot wait for whatever Daniel Mullins releases next

Addicting and fun card game with a really interesting story and a boat load of cool and creative mechanics. A lot of the fun comes from customising your own cards and using the games mechanics to form your own strategies and plays.

[NO MAJOR SPOILERS]
The first act of the game lives up to exactly what is promised in the promotional videos - a grim, dark, naturalistic card game mixed with escape room elements and mystery. This phase lasts 4-5 hours.

After this first act is over, without spoiling details, the rug gets pulled out from under you and the entire game changes for the worse. The atmosphere becomes stale, the mechanics less fun, the mystery is lost. The game goes from being a 10/10 to being a 4/10 just because the author is trying to be special and "artsy" by having this fourth wall breaking "game within a game" experience.

If the game was just Act 1, with 3x the content, designed for replayability, this game would be a 10. You can unlock an endless mode after beating the game, but honestly the whole atmosphere is ruined after finishing it.

It's an awesome game. It's difficult though until you figure out how to play it and there are many ways to play. Basically you are building your deck of cards as you go, making it progressively stronger. Every round you start with the same deck and some cards are dealt from it randomly. You have to use bones and play sacrifice cards to play even stronger cards. There are 4 bosses. I tried to play this half a dozen times and kept dying and couldn't tell what to do exactly. But I just beat the game and man it was tense. Loved it. There are puzzles you can solve around the room to gain some powerful cards - that's one thing I was missing. The Stoat talking card gives you the first clue. Somehow I didn't think it was important but it is. Also there are drawers on the wall you can solve and open to get a whole bunch of great cards. That's the boost I needed.
