After finishing this game to the fullest, I'd have to say it was one of the best designed games I've ever played (mechanically). The game has a great tutorial, which introduces all the important mechanics seamlessly. It even provides a great challenge if you play the game again from the beginning and try to make it to the end on the first run!

The mechanics themselves are really nuanced and lead to very thoughtful gameplay, even with not that much to have to look at, I would still find myself thinking long and hard about every move I made to survive the difficult situation in front of me, or to capitalist on the non-difficult situation in front of me.

Despite requiring a lot of thinking sometimes (especially in [spoiler] Kaycee's Mod [/spoiler]) there is always plenty of room to make mistakes and goof around. And if you DO want to put in though in a relatively safe situation, the game always rewards you for it. You get more teeth the more damage you do past what you need, using less items can give you special cards, or you can even set up for paintings. The list goes on.

I also love how the style of the game fits so well with the mechanics. It really feels like a fight for your life where anything goes, especially with the items. It feels really despite to pull your teeth out and what not. And the way that Leshy takes the rules of the game so seriously and even gets annoyed when [spoiler] You get a third candle from the painting [/spoiler] or [spoiler] Kaycee nerfs fecundity [/spoiler].

As far as the story and secrets go, the game handles them both together and pretty well. The game will set up something mysterious that it will satisfyingly pay off later. There are TONS of smaller examples, but some of the biggest secrets lead to some of the best story moments. For example, the game sets up that there is something behind the door, and in most games it might just be atmosphere, but in this game, it's actually the most important thing in the room! I won't say much more other than that, but basically, whenever I saw something weird or was curious about something, there was almost ALWAYS something there (and not just in the story/room segments, in the card game too, like sigil interactions and whatnot.)

As far as the main story goes, it's great! There are a lot of great moments that you should probably go in blind for. And don't let looks deceive you there is a lot more to the game than what's on the Steam page. Though, the game doesn't get much harder after that point, just new mechanics. If your into the secret hunting and following the mysteries you find, there's lots in store for you! If you just care about the challenge of the card game and the story isn't for you, then there is more for you after you beet the game:

After [spoiler] getting the "Dramatic Finale" achievement [/spoiler] you unlock [spoiler] Kaycee's mod, where you can re-battle Leshy with different starting decks and challenges and most of the room mechanics are disabled and a lot of the op mechanics like campfires, fecundity, and moon cheesing are nerfed, this is where the challenge really picks up. [/spoiler]

It's for everyone to decide themselves when they are done with a game. If you were in it for the story, you'll be done after beating the game. But if you enjoy following secrets and want to figure out all the answers to those questions you were wondering, the game has only just begun. For me, getting all the achievements was satisfactory for me, but I could probably still challenge myself more in [spoiler] Kaycee's Mod [/spoiler] though it would just be arbitrary challenges for my own sake at that point which, in my opinion, ruins the whole anything goes feel of the game, and I don't feel like I'm accomplishing anything. But if you like to challenge yourself, there's hundreds of hours of fun waiting for you.

Overall, it's still just a game about playing cards, but you better believe it's the best game about playing cards I've ever played!

"That‚Äôs okay, let‚Äôs keep playing. We don‚Äôt need to keep track." 

I spotted this game in my friend's collections and had noticed them playing it a bit. I had no idea what I was about to get myself into... I'll do my best to keep this as spoiler free as possible. 

The gameplay is fascinating and quick to learn, I finished the game and I'm on my second run through, and still finding all sorts of new things that I missed the first time! The game starts off simple in theory, and then begins to progress and pull you into this crazy story. The mechanics are wonderful, and at times I was forgetting I was playing the same game. 

This is a perfect game for anyone who loves mystery, deep cryptic lore, lowkey horror vibes, and looking for a unique game and story to begin playing. It combines strategy wonderfully with its lore. It's addictive, from the very start, I couldn't put it down. There were twists after turns after twists, and it catered to my inner love for cryptic mystery and Trading Card Games. The developers absolutely put so much love into this game. From the function balance, to even how some of the characters resemble types of TCG players you'd play against. 

The plot is concrete - it adds a sense of mystery. Questions are being answered (and being created) as I'm playing through my second play through. The second play through has been giving me time to really appreciate all the foreshadowing and setup that was placed into the plot from the very beginning. 

And functionally? Oh my God. There are Three Acts to this game -- each one just as interesting as the last. I was baffled when switching between them as the play style gets very interesting and very different very quickly. I was baffled and left stunned at the end of the game, and needed to take a moment to actually think about what had happened. And then, of course, I went right back into it with more questions that I HAD to get answered. 

Highly recommend for anyone looking for some fun meta-game type lore to add to their gaming repertoire.

I keep coming back to this one. Its a card game consisting of three acts.

Act 1: This part has amazing atmosphere. A psychopath holds you prisoner in his log cabin and forces you to play his homebrew card game. It is somewhat like MtG or Hearthstone, but with deck-building and rogue elements. Your captor pulls out a map to use as a gameboard, and basically does a table-top roleplay of your character travelling through several places. You choose which places to go to, which net you different opportunities to adjust the cards in your deck in different ways. You are playing to survive, both figuratively and literally. If you enjoyed the deck-building elements and dealer from Hand of Fate, you'll especially enjoy this.

Act 2: The game transforms into a card RPG with 2D graphics in the vein of Pokemon TCG on gameboy, or Sacred Cards on gba. You are dumped into a card-themed world, and have to duel everyone using some of what you've learned in Act 1, but with some new mechanics added in. This is the most controversial part of the game, since it excises the atmosphere of Act 1. I ended up liking this part quite a lot, even if it is a pretty big departure from the previous act. I don't blame anyone who had trouble with this part, since being good at reading the board is more important than ever. I didn't have too much trouble thankfully - experimentation is key here.

Act 3: The game switches back to the Act 1 format with a different character - you are held prisoner in a technology themed place by someone who forgoes the atmospheric treatment of Act 1. Pretty good mechanically, and the atmosphere isn't that bad even if it doesn't reach the heights of Act 1.

Kaycee's Mod: An add-on was created for the game which has the player run through Act 1 with some optional handicaps. I beta tested this, and I have to say it's pretty terrible. Basically a russian roulette simulator. At best, it's just Act 1 over and over with few new experiences.

Custom mods: There are an awful lot of them on thunderstore. I tried to use some of them, but the process is not user friendly. Too many scattered components are needed and not explained well.

As someone who hates card games, I absolutely loved this one. The mechanics are simple and easy to understand within an hour instead of having to scratch your head about how viable each card is to use at any moment. It's more of a puzzle game. On top of that, the mysterious story that comes along with it is extremely engaging and fun to uncover. The atmosphere, sound design, and ambiance is really great as well. This is a fantastic game to play on a Steam Deck OLED as a result. I highly recommend this game and anything else by this dev team.
Awesome and unique game. I don't have much to say other than to buy it.

1st act :
great art that you can tell was crafted carefully to build tension and set your expectations going forward.
spooky backwoods horror atmosphere really demands your attention from the word go.
deck building was unique and tied into a mysterious story that only gave you a few puzzle pieces to sink it's hooks into your intrigue.
2nd act:
Throws that all out the window for a 16bt poke'undertale'mon mess that looks nothing like the 1st act.
Intriguing plots devolve into a crazy narrative pile that goes nowhere and characters actions seem completely haphazard because we don't know much of anything about them or their motivations.  The deck building gets broken into individual parts and offers a unsatisfyingly basic play dynamic.
3rd act:
Tries to take a page from the 1st act and reestablish the setting but with a different theme.  You feel like things are back on track until you are set with a mobile game walk around and another new deck building mechanic.  Story went off the rails in the 2nd act and now it's just a smoldering heap that's just randomly lurching and hissing at you until it ends.  Leaving you with questions that you don't care enough to find the answers too.

overall: 4 outa' 10
not worth it.

a combination of two indie game scenes i have next to no interest in (deckbuilders and roguelites), by a guy whos last quirky crazy meta game i thought was Nice but maybe not anything i havent rly seen before, and the result is, if maybe not an all-time favorite, certainly one of those things that just makes me think that maybe video games are the best medium after all. the mechanical unity is rly key to this one's success vs the vignettes of pony island or something similar like frog fractions...no matter what happens, yr always playing a very enjoyable card game that takes advantage of its non-symmetrical pve style to the fullest extent, with enjoyable and surprising iterations throughout. all thats left is for it to deliver an enjoyable creepypasta that speaks at least a few emotional truths about competing creative visions, and maybe creativity in general. the disarming sentimentality that graces moments of the finale is well earned...there is much to be attached to, in the intimacy of learning how to play, and in the desire to give everything a Voice to be heard and understood

If you enjoy deckbuilders and card casting/trading card games like we do, you simply NEED to try Inscryption!  Not saying this is the only game of it's kind with Roguelike elements, but it's the first that we've played and honestly, it is/was amazing!

The RNG keeps you on your toes, and having to constantly think about ways to evolve your deck to match your current run keeps you hooked and playing for hours.  I would have never imagined a mashup like this, but it was done beautifully.  Odd in a game that is set in a macabre cabin with pixelated, horror-themed visuals!

There are three distinct acts in the game, each playing very different than the one before it.  It seems that when Inscryption is searched online, only visuals of Act 1 are shown.  The following two acts could easily be their own games in their own right.  New mechanics, new decks, new maps and styles of play, AND new cards are introduced as well.

AND JUST WHEN YOU THINK YOU'VE FINISHED, there's Kaycee's Mod.  Basically an expansion to the Act 1 base game, but in a tiered presentation instead.  You'll find yourself fighting through the same four maps from Act 1, but with the ability to add challenge skull modifiers while unlocking new starter decks to try with the completion of every other successful run (similar to the challenge skulls in Halo).

We just 100%'d the game at nearly 80 hours, and now, admittedly there isn't much left to do.  Replayability, could continue to be a thing if you wanted to test different things and strategies, but for now we'll wait and see if anything gets added to this game.  We'd be back in a heartbeat.

THANK YOU Inscryption, for a truly unique gaming experience - one we're sure not soon to forget!

Are you interested in the world of trading card games? Do you wanna keep trusting the heart of the cards? You won't get an Exodia The Forbidden One, but your cards can be shred to pieces.. More pieces than the ones you would have to gather before trying to summon the aforementioned creature. So keep in mind there‚Äôs no turning back or salvation for your poor little companions. Not even a referee will be able to say: since that invocation is banned in competitions you can keep the parts again! Let me tell you that here, this is not going to happen‚Ä¶ You will have to fight and strengthen your deck, yes, but for your own survival. So‚Ä¶ Like a famous card duelist once quoted: It 's time to du-du-duel!

Okay time to get serious here * BRAIN PLEASE NO MORE YU-GI-OH REFERENCES!*

The story is one plot twist after another, and let me tell you that never in my life have I enjoyed a card game so much. The mechanics are the most polished I ever found in a game of this kind, the originality of the matches, the story itself and even the design is, simply put, mind blowing. Even the non existent tutorial and the way they guide you to learn all the game mechanics that keep piling up one after another is brilliant.
Sometimes you will not know what to expect next and that will keep your survival instinct at the highest level possible, so you can just stare at everyone with suspicious eyes not knowing if you can even trust your own cards anymore.
The power of friendship will not help your deck to improve and keep getting deadlier, your choices will. So be careful cause sometimes the devil likes to wear prada and other times he likes to bust your deck out of existence.
Are you not photogenic? Don't worry! Your fear of cameras may even be useful to you‚Ä¶

My personal advice to survive this journey is: DON‚ÄôT TRUST ANYONE, NOT YOUR FRIENDS FROM STEAM, NOT YOUR OWN CARDS, AND NOT EVEN YOURSELF!

Personally, I believe Inscryption is one of those games that you have to experience firsthand, and give it a chance, but better do it without seeing anything previously.. So the events that are going to happen end up catching you by surprise.. There are some moments that even reached my heart. 
[spoiler]I cried, not gonna lie when you are almost at the end of the game and the opponents thoughts at the last moments of their life were only wanting to give you a handshake because they considered you a worthy rival‚Ä¶.[/spoiler]
I bought and completed this game on PS4 and then started to play it on steam, even though I‚Äôm not so fond of card-based games tbh.

The developer even released a free update which unlocks the infinite mode for the card du-du-duels!

The First 1/3 of the game is really fun despite the card game mechanics being a little shallow - the overall atmosphere and storytelling is great. The second 1/3 feels a bit undercooked and loses a lot of the aesthetic appeal of Act 1 without improving the gameplay much at all. The third act is by far the worst, being an eyesore slog through really boring fights. I wish Act 1 was the entire game with extended content/more opportunities to grow your deck/ more bosses.

Aside from the gameplay the narrative twists feel really derivative of other "fourth-wall breaking" indie games (see Undertale mostly).
Right now I just don't think this game is worth the price tag, maybe pick it up for 5-10 bucks.

Inscryption, like Slay the Spire is a deck-builder where you traverse a map across 3 levels, but the unique aesthetics and storytelling make this game really engaging and with successive runs you discover more and more secrets about the spooky cabin you find yourself trapped in. The game helps you learn about the combat system by introducing more complex sigils (combat modifiers) after repeated runs. There seems to be a good amount of replayability, some progression elements, and lots of hidden achievements and secrets to discover! I'm really enjoying the game so far.

Inscryption is a clever and captivating roguelike with a very intriguing story, an expansive and diverse set of mechanics, and an incredible atmosphere. The shocking twists and turns the player encounters as the story progresses ensure that every moment leaves you unsure of what will happen next, and sometimes even a bit uncertain as to what has already happened, encouraging you to piece together the narrative yourself. This game incorporates a variety of genres, including puzzle, horror, and classic RPG, yet none of the game's moments feel out of place, and instead everything blends together in a uniquely perfect way. Inscryption is easy to learn, but hard to master, creating a very high skill ceiling and allowing for boundless replayability. All-in-all an excellent card-battling roguelike at its core, with a dark, immersive, mysterious story surrounding it.

My main complaint is that it's so dark it's impossible to see things on the Steam deck. I use the deck because I'm visually impaired, and even with the in-game brightness maximized, I had to stream the game from desktop with remote play so that I could ALSO stream to Discord and have my friends help me with navigating at points - seeing cards during events on the map, seeing the clues for puzzles, seeing the puzzles themselves, and sitting back down at the table the map is on after standing up and walking around - simply because it was so unbelievably DARK. I know a creepy game is supposed to have the atmosphere, but a few extra notches of brightness settings for those of us who need it would be greatly appreciated. I'd like to be able to see the faces in boss battles, for example.

I fully enjoyed this as someone who doesn't play card games. Well worth the price. I'll add some vague spoilers/references to elaborate on this, but don't read on if you want a completely blind run.

I went in and fully enjoyed Act 1. I didn't know there was more game past that and was satisfied with the ending at that point, but then Act 2 came in and completely shifted the meta. I found the changes to gameplay pretty fun still. 

Act 3 slowed to a halt though. It feels pretty impossible without specific breaking with ourobot and the gameplay loop just isn't fun. I understand that the monotony and blandness is the thematic portrayal that's being attempted, but it didn't work for me. I had zero enjoyment and did not finish. I looked at a playthrough to see the ending and it looks satisfying, but I couldn't justify trudging through the segment to get there. 

With that it left a sour taste in my mouth. I'm sure I'd like the roguelike mode you get on completion, but I feel complete with the portions of the game I finished.

First turn kills are a problem, even on the second map, given that you have so little life. This reduces the dynamics to an all-or-nothing scenario. The chances for deck-building and strategy are limited.

EDIT:
I just finished the "tutorial" act, without any spoilers or online help. It was soooooo repetitive. I won with absolutely broken cards which doesn't provide much satisfaction. So my previous comments were correct, as far as that goes. 

However, the overall game is so unique that I am going to change my thumb to the moon --- er, I mean up --- position.

The Best of its genre. This will be a largely spoiler-free review to the best of my ability. It is a challenging game to review at any length without spoilers, but I won't put any in here. In truth, Inscryption is one of the best games ever made and is easily the number one in its genre. How the developers fused a deck-building game with psychological horror, two polar opposite genres, into one game is nothing short of something worth being universally lauded. The game starts in a cabin with a mysterious figure. You can't leave the cabin, and this figure, who acts as a sort of Dungeon Master, leads the game, and you play along. Most of the game is deck-building and playing with its unique rules. It's easy to learn, and you'll likely find it the most enjoyable part. The gameplay for the card-playing aspects is genuinely fun. Around the cabin, you've got little things to do; you can leave the table at more or less any time, and a few puzzles to solve that are worth doing and will aid you in your quest to beat the mysterious cabin figure. That being said, I'll mostly end my review here; the game only gets better the more you play it, and you'll be pleasantly surprised at what you find. The writing is phenomenal and philosophical, as well as downright sadistic. The Soundtrack is also an absolute banger. I'll recommend this game to anyone and everyone. It's genuinely some of the most fun I've had last year. 10/10. Daniel Mullins is fucking genius. Please don't wait for a sale; it's worth the full price; go and get it!

This game is incredibly fun - it's a card deck building game with a meta-storyline that is super unique to anything I've played lately. The music is great, the concept within the game is great, and the way it eases you into the mechanics of the gameplay is great. EVERYTHING IS GREAT. The only thing I wish is that I could wipe my playthrough from my brain to enjoy it again.

Extremely solid card game with a story that makes you curious to find out more and figure it all out. If you've played his other game, "Pony Island" then you'll be happy to see the quirky computer tricks are also in this game as well. He's a creator who's work I'm always excited to play and enjoy. The game's biggest strength is it's atmosphere, which is incredibly unique and diverse. 

Personally, I think the acts are all quite good - they do play pretty differently though even if mechanics carry over. I think the different visual style of act 2 throws people off, but that act is very heavy on having a solid first turn, so I understand the mild frustration. If I'm being honest, I prefer Acts 1 and 3 overall, but Act 2 is still very enjoyable. 

My only critique really is that sometimes the writing can go from clever and mysterious to a bit obtuse at times, and the videos you find have some strange acting beats. Nothing awful or cringe worthy, but a smidge distracting at times.

I have never been into deck-building games and yet I found this game really addictive. The mechanics & rules of the card game require you to think way ahead and of multiple possibilities which allow you to come up with strategies with a satisfying payoff. The game combines its strong card game with a really good soundtrack, environment & story to make it more than just a card game. The game comes up with twists & plot points that no one can expect. Although Act 1 of the game has the most engaging gameplay the later acts are still fun to play & manage to keep you just as engaged with its introductions to more gameplay mechanics, rules & story. Overall it's a really good game even if you are not into deck-building games & definitely will give you one of the most unique gaming experiences.

Solid NO from me ... I don't get why this game is Overwhelmingly Positive.  I came to play a deck builder and I got something that wasn't really what I expected.  I don't get all of the interactive "stuff" that's in the cabin.  So I guess there's some escape room stuff, but who cares?  I managed to unlock a few things that one of the talking cards said to do and it unlocked another talking card ... and these cards had a dialog that I couldn't care less about.

The game sort of plays out like a Magic the Gathering style where you have to sacrifice cards to pay the costs of the real cards you want to play.  Some cards cost blood, others bones.  If there's other costs then I don't know because I gave up.

Comparing to a few other roguelike deck builders:

Slay the Spire is the GOAT and one of the first that really nails the game loop nicely.

Chrono Ark seems to have a much deeper story and more variety with different characters you can team up with.

Tainted Grail: Conquest has gameplay that is on-par with StS but is completely oozing with creepy atmosphere and storytelling and I've loved every minute playing that game.

Others I've enjoyed include Loop Hero, Stacklands, and the campy Neoverse.

At any rate, give any and all of the above your money because I think they're more enjoyable and pass on Inscryption.

Its the best card based game I've ever played. I enjoyed Slay the Spire quite a but this feels like the ultimate realization of that concept. The live action cutscenes that I was totally not expecting. The fact that its like 3 or 4 games in one. The satisfaction of planning a deck perfectly and absolutely wrecking the final boss when it all comes together. The mostly optional but really entertaining side puzzles that unlock tangible, useful rewards. It really just has everything I'd ever want from a deck builder. The only criticism I can even think of is the ugly art style of the cards themselves. They are far from enjoyable to look at. I don't think it would have changed much to just make the animals look like something other than a quick sketch. Really great game

Inscryption is a dark and wonderful game with several secrets hidden throughout. Although the majority of the game is based around deck building and puzzle-solving, Inscryption does an amazing job at conveying a sense of horror and an unsettling atmosphere. Characters give subtle hints about the game's outcome and occasionally reveal bits of lore, letting you pick up the pieces as the game progresses.

If you‚Äôre a fan of deck building and card-game strategy games, you will absolutely love this game.  The developer has also included a special mode that allows endless replayability of the first section (though I've yet to try this part myself). If you are such a player, you can confidently skip the rest of this review and buy the game! However, if you aren't a fan of deck building games, you should keep reading.


Factors to Consider:

A. An Intriguing Plot

The plot of Inscryption is laced with mystery. Questions like ‚ÄúWhy does the game exist?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhy is there no information about it online?‚Äù, and ‚ÄúWhat secrets does the game hold?‚Äù might draw your attention as you play and experience the game and see the story from the protagonist‚Äôs eyes.

Here‚Äôs a quick summary of the plot‚Äôs beginning:

[spoiler]The story shows Luke Carder, a card-collecting YouTuber, who found a mysterious game out in the woods after receiving coordinates from an old Inscryption card pack. Luke is curious and begins to question the game's existence and contacts the company that made the cards, GameFuna, after finding no information online. This company states that no such game exists and threatens legal action if the property in question is not returned to them. Luke ignores their warning and continues his playthrough and investigation into the game's hidden secrets.[/spoiler]


B. Gameplay

As mentioned earlier, Inscryption's gameplay heavily leans on deck building and strategy. As an enthusiast of these types of games, I found Inscryption to be particularly satisfying. Defeating Leshy, the first main boss you meet, gives me a great sense of accomplishment. The rest of the game continues to provide this same feeling as you progress and beat each character.

The rest of the gameplay heavily involves environmental exploration and puzzle-solving, which I found equally enjoyable. As I was playing, I found myself deeply immersed in the story and the carefully thought-out environment. Unfortunately, these aspects of the game are not replayable. Once the main game and puzzles are finished and solved, there‚Äôs nothing left to discover, apart from a few secrets or missed interactions. It‚Äôs worth noting that the replayable mode might offer additional secrets, puzzles, and changes to gameplay, but I cannot comment on it in this review since I haven‚Äôt played it yet.

C. Difficulty & Learning

To start, it might be difficult to remember the effects of each card type or how to use the various elements present in the game, but I found that it was rather easily picked up over time. Even after taking a substantial break from the game, I was able to quickly relearn the mechanics just by playing.


Conclusion:

In conclusion, Inscription is a captivating experience that combines deck-building and puzzle-solving with a dark, mysterious plot. The game provides players with an immersive and unsettling atmosphere, driving you forward with appropriate challenges in each section. Though the game initially seems complex, most of the mechanics can be easily picked up and learned over time, even after significant breaks between play-sessions. Once the game is finished and all the puzzles are solved, there is little left to explore in the main game, but players may find new experiences contained in the included replayable mode. If you‚Äôre a fan of deck-building strategy games, or if you just enjoy a good mystery, Inscryption just might be the game for you.

For the first 6 or so hours of this game I was enjoying getting increasingly skilled at a rewarding and lore-ridden deck builder. And then...let's just say whatever you think Inscryption is for the first few hours is probably not what it is. 10/10.

The actual card game and varieties are cool, although neither new nor unique for a MTG & Hearthstone veteran.

The big problem I had, on release: Youtube algorithm showed me spoilers for all the major twists in the game in recommended videos thumbnails. On clickbait videos. But, to be fair, that is not the game's fault. However, I have something constructive to say as a result.

The game is very linear. Knowing what will happen from Youtube images, I deliberately was trying to create a different outcome in my game. And the game sometimes provides you with explicit choices. Fake choices. The game PRESENTS itself as a more open-ended one. Please don't do that, developers. I just felt worse shortly after getting spoiled.

I was meaning to come back to it, but for what? To see (ending spoilers, that are my guess on events) [spoiler]Luke Carder die and P03 get trapped in hardware containing the software Pony Island style[/spoiler]? What's the point? For a glorified MTG minigame?

It's now been over a year since I first played this game and wrote my original review. In that time, I've played Inscryption through several times, written over a dozen fanfictions for it, drawn a ton of fanart, crafted a Leshy cosplay, and stayed active in the community for months. I've also watched numerous dissections of the plot and ARGs of all the main Mullinsverse games, and am actively looking forward to Pony Island 2.

Does this mean my opinion on Inscryption has changed?

Well, sort of.

The game does a massive disservice to itself by hiding everything after Act 1. I've seen so many posts of people getting incredibly frustrated with the unexpected direction Acts 2 and 3 take, and I personally make a point of spoiling the game whenever I recommend it. This is a game best enjoyed when you're not surprised by the drastic change in visual aesthetics, but the spoiler culture around Inscryption has left the fandom stunted and divided. I actually prefer Act 2 above all others for the more diverse card sets and mechanics, but also for the scant worldbuilding it provides.

This game is a slave to its meta elements, with the in-world storytelling left in tatters and the ARG in a domineering yet understated role. As an ARG, it's physically impossible to solve on one's own, which means that understanding the greater plot without scrounging around the internet or watching an hour-long video isn't doable. Inscryption's reliance on The Hex and possibly Pony Island 2 for plot details is also only to its detriment. Why should a fan of this game have to be a fan of the entire Mullinsverse just to comprehend the most basic of details? It seems Inscryption can't even get its own lore sorted, with the timeline of Kaycee's Mod seemingly contradicting the timeline of the main game. Luke learns Kaycee died a long time ago, and the format of Inscryption as a floppy disk game inspired by GameBoy Pokemon games makes the idea that Kaycee was programming this while Youtube existed a baffling paradox.

And yet despite the frustration and irritation I feel towards so many aspects of this game...I'm still playing it. I'm still in the fandom, writing and drawing and sewing and theorizing along with so many other people. There's something about the whole package that's irresistibly alluring, the mystique of its characters so tantalizing, that it's hard to quit this game. I want to know more about Magnificus and his students. I want to know more about Sado and Rebecha and GameWorks and how they all tie together. I want to see the plot untangled and dissected and laid out in a somewhat-sensical way. And I want to theorize and headcanon and create new ideas based on all the loose plot threads that I have no way of knowing whether Mullins will resolve in his next game or leave hanging forever.

It's that frustration and annoyance that leaves so many holes for a fandom to fill. The fans of this game can be so creative and the relatively small size of the community means there's little drama outside of people arguing about whether P03 or Magnificus are more morally corrupt (both camps are wrong; Grimora is actually the worst and no I will not budge on that opinion). I hate Inscryption and I don't recommend it for anything outside of its fun but bitterly easy gameplay. But I want everyone to play it and get mad and use that rage to create beautiful things out of it. Get sucked into it. Join me in this hell of our own making. You'll love it here.

I loved this game. There was so much I loved, and some things I didn't. Here's those. Spoilers ahead.

Positive:
For some context, I come from MTG, and am the type of person to not care in the slightest about lore. I like optimizing.
With that said, the spooky aesthetic act 1 was perfect. The glowing white eyes peering at you constantly, the dark atmosphere, the sounds, everything about that vibe was great. The gameplay is really fun and interesting, the resource system reminds me almost of treasure tokens from MTG. I quite liked it. I see many negative reviews from people saying it's too challenging with less than 5 hours playtime, and I don't want to be that guy, but you gotta get good at it. Theres things to learn, challenging puzzles, and so so so many decisions. I'm the type of person who buys games for that kind of stuff, I get that that's not everyone's cup of tea though. This may not be for you if it's not. I am a big fan of act 2's aesthetic, and the gameplay there is great too. I love the deckbuilding system, and the fact you can control every card in your deck and make tiny adjustments rather than in act 1 where you are at the mercy of the random events and the cards you find or get rid of is great imo. And I haven't even mentioned Kaycee's mod yet, it feels like learning how to play the game again every time I choose a new starter deck or strategy which I love. Still haven't managed to do skullstorm, but the fact that after a few days of nonstop trying to figure this game out there's still things I can't do is what keeps me playing.

Now for the negative:
As for act 1, where the jumpscares at? After I realized there was nothing startling and I could take my time even when told not to, I didn't really feel on edge anymore which took away some of the experience for me. The first hour or two every time I would get up or open something I would be bracing for something to pop out at me, but after a while I was just going about my business. I'm not sure if I love or hate the pain in the ass that is trying to keep your deck size and quality down, it's quite tedious. As for the bosses, the first couple are much harder than the final one IMO. I'm not sure that's a bad thing though? You finally after hours of work beat the first two, it feels good to breeze through the final boss, but still feels wrong to me. Act 2, only thing I didn't love was the lack of explanation for the energy and magic mechanics. They just plop you into this world with multiple intertwined new mechanics and no clear explanation of how to use them. I still don't fully get circuits or magic, I never really had a reason to put in the effort to teach myself. Now for the big part, act 3 was ugly. I hated the look. It goes from old cabin in the woods to retro game to like, mid 2000s depiction of a hologram table? The gameplay was alright but significantly worse than acts 1 and 2, although I will admit the bosses were great. Po3 being annoying the whole time was also, well, annoying.

Overall 9/10, really good game if you have the right expectation of what it is. It is not just in the cabin. I love it, some don't.

While this game is a wonderful thematic exploration of card games, any closer inspection reveals an ARG that is comically strung together and ruins the impact and meaningful writing of this game, and it's established gameplay loop. Hopefully going forward we can have this silly Dan Mullins ARG put to rest seeing how it tainted this otherwise legitimately perfect game.

Edit 03/21/22 : Kaycee's mod adds a interesting varient to the first phase of the game that creates an endless ascension mode. The adventure and lore building in this mode is quite weak, the new cards cause more problems than they offer solutions, and while the starter decks are fun, the ultimate reward is extremely underwhelming. The mode itself also shows the many flaws of phase 1's card and encounter design. While this does not ruin the game it certainly leaves it worse than it was. I am somewhat glad the developers are leaving the project, as iteration made it worse not better.

Act 1 of this game is a deck builder card battle game. Less "CCG" like M:tG, where your goal is to acquire boosters to get great cards, and more like dominion or codex, where you have chances along the way to choose 1 of three every so often, and custom build a deck, one card at a time.

You are fighting with cards that have strength and health; health damage carries over from turn to turn, so cards wear out and must be replaced.

Most cards have a sacrifice cost; you spend cards placed on the board to bring out new cards. You can draw either a "free" 0-1 squirrel, or one of the good cards from your deck that require killing something. After your first death, you start to get cards with a cost of "bones" -- and every time something dies, you get at least one of those for free. So, instead of putting cards into resources, or land, you use them up, constantly cycling them.

Things you can kill: Squirrels, or cards that have used up almost all of their health from previous turns.

The game board -- there are 4 lanes, and most cards cannot change lanes, and only attack straight forward. Your opponent plays their cards one turn ahead of time -- so you see where it will be in time to do something about it. There is no "summoning sickness" -- all cards attack the turn they are placed, and defenders do not deal damage in response. So board tempo is critical, and can switch instantly.

Definitely get the demo to see how the card combat works. It only reveals the first boss, and there are at least three that I have seen so far, plus at least one more that I have not.

There is a lot to this card battle part of the game, and this is apparently only act 1 of three.
There is an option, after winning, to enable a "long-term card battle" mode, where the card battle part of the game keeps going. This is the main portion of the game.

UPDATE AFTER FINISHING GAME WITHOUT KM:
Ok good. interesting mechanics. But still, that's too much. The game literally almost endless.

Act 1 is so much fun. The style the game takes on is super cool. The eeriness of the cabin, as well as who you're opposing, creates such an interesting mood. The card game itself is addicting. Although it may seem unfair when you die to a boss and have to restart, upgrading cards, discovering new ones, solving puzzles, and slowly building that extremely overpowered card make the journey feel exciting rather than sluggish. Discovering a strat to use on a boss you previously thought was just straight-up unfair is so satisfying and would give me the same rush Souls games would. The mystery behind what the hell is even happening is intriguing and keeps you wanting to play. 

...That is until you finish the relatively short first act. Which also happens to be the ONLY act you see on the store page, or anyone playing online. The second act has you play a 16-bit top-down RPG. There's still a card game, but the fundamentals have completely changed and it's just not as fun. The deck building is wonky and 80% of the cards are unplayable and will cause you to lose every encounter. The change in style made things somewhat hard to read (and just annoying) and I simply didn't care to be as involved with my deck as I did in the first act and had one randomized for me. The third act is not as bad, but it's mediocre and lost me entirely. It's a different card game from the first two, and it's just boring this time. There's no intrigue or mystery anymore. It almost feels like you're playing for nothing and the setting/mood isn't interesting. Arguably worse than the second act due to it being so unbelievably mediocre. 

I get contextually why the game changes with the story, and to be fair, it's a cool concept! It just doesn't work in this case. The story means nothing to me if the game isn't consistently fun and no amount of writing or gimmicks can make up for gameplay (IMO). I don't care how eccentric they are. It's disingenuous advertising because they want to keep a "mystique" to the game, but it really feels like it's just because they know the first act is the only one worth playing.

A beautiful Rogue-like Deckbuilder. Great story, characters, and just enough information left out to make it entirely spooky. There are some broken combos and cheaty cards, but you can always choose if you want to build toward them or not. Plus, you feel super smart when you figure them out.

I won't spoil anything, but I can't help but wonder how many people only played this long enough to think it was just a card game. At its heart, that's exactly what Inscryption is, and it's a good one. Right when I finally developed a working strategy and started to get hooked, everything changed, and the game morphed right in front of my eyes, practically switching genres entirely on the fly.

Credit to the developer for creating something unlike anything else, and the card game itself is absolutely worth the price of the product by itself, but things got a little too meta for me by the end. I don't mind a twist or two here and there, but we veered so far off the original course that I wasn't even sure what I was playing anymore by the last half of the game.

Still, anyone who enjoys well-crafted card games should give this one a chance, and if you like surprises, all the better. I admire the developer for thinking so outside the box here, and I imagine there are all sorts of interesting ideas floating around in that mind of his. I may not have been fully on board with where Inscryption took me in the end, but I'm not going to forget the experience anytime soon. That's something truly worth of praise, and it makes the decision to recommend the game an easy one despite whatever misgivings I have about the ending.

I've enjoyed Half-Life, Halo, The Elder Scrolls, Little Big Planet, Celeste, Call of Duty, Minecraft, Mario, Kirby, Sonic, Zelda, Plants vs. Zombies, Gears of War, Undertale, and more. I thought I had understood the value of video games, and how incredible of an art form they are, but... I feel like my third eye has been opened.

What an experience! Not JUST as a video game, but as an absolutely magical and captivating work of art. You think the game is one thing, but then it throws out everything that you thought you knew about it, and does nothing but continue to expand more, and more. Right off the bat, you are plunged into this highly detailed cabin, with captivating ear candies and tiny details for the immersion, and a mysterious atmosphere that does not let you escape. You will always come back to this game, until the very end.

Inscryption is...a deck-building puzzle game set in a cosmical horror setting. It's not the first indie game to take several apparently disjointed elements and mix them together harmoniously. However, I feel Inscryption is remarquable for two things :
- it's not just harmonious mixing, each of the three aspects I mentionned (deck-building, puzzles, and cosmical horror setting) feed one into another, gameplay into lore into gameplay, and so on and so on.
- there is something for everyone here. You can enjoy this game very surface-level, or delve very, and I mean, very deep, both in its gameplay and its lore.

And to say anything more would be a shame. What everyone is saying is true, the less you know, the better. Just try it, and see for yourself!

Inscryption is a horror themed card game with a huge amount of twists. One of the few times a game has both conveyed its feelings and story so unanimously I was hooked the  entire time. The visuals, music, and graphics support the horror feel as well as the feeling of danger that comes with playing the game. Mechanics are extremely unique and interesting and there is such a feeling of confusion that I miss when I first played Inscyption. I enjoyed the whole experience and the post game content is enthralling; Addicted to the infinite rogue-like post game content of course. 

Before going into spoiler territory, I would like to address the common feeling that people get once they finish Act 1. As the game is sliced into three main story acts, commonly, people are dissapointed by what Act 2 and 3 have to offer. I don't understand how someone will spend 4-6 hours playing through Act 1, gain so much trust in the game's ability to be competent, and immediately quit as soon as the status quo of the main game is challenged. Acts 2 and 3 fit into the narrative perfectly and the game play while different, still keeps its core mechanics and tone that the player is used to in Act 1. There is definitely a whiplash of style in Act 2, but it only adds to the story and does not detract from it. For those who quit after running around Act 2 for a little bit, this chapter is actually quite short and can be completed extremely fast if you know what you're doing. I would recommend revisiting the game especially since Act 3 kicks back into more of what the player is expecting. 

STORY AND GAME PLAY SPOILERS
[spoiler] The overall connection between the in game events as well as the ARG that has already been solved is extremely interesting especially with the meta analysis that Inscryption presents. Because you play as an actual player of the game, the 4th wall breaking moments in-game are extremely charming and pose a lot of questions. Moments such as P3 asking for your files on your computer, Leshy talking about the previous players that have died, and the game being discussed in meta by the scrybes. The story of the scrybes is extremely interesting and each have amazing character designs and personalities. One thing about the story is that I REALLY wish that there was more. There could be sooooo many interesting writing moments between Grimora and P3 for example. Continuing the cycle of each scribe taking over the game. Close to the final moments of the game, you get to play another card game with Grimora, and I wished to have another act where we play this chess game that she presents to us. I also feel that a lot of the card mechanics are under-utilised in Kaycee's mod. Specifically p3's and Magnificus' card selections. Both have interesting mechanics and I would love to see it in the infinite rogue-like format. These aren't particularly complaints, just something I really wish existed, possibly as a DLC. [/spoiler]

Act 1: This feels like what Hands of Fate should have been (Hands of fate tried to incorporate terrible combat mechanics into what otherwise a good card building, atmospheric game.) Have been enjoying it, but there the RNG does definitely factor in to how each run is going to go and can cause you to be sent back to the beginning on an unlucky draw so be warned if that's something you don't want to deal with.  You basically collect cards, upgrade them where possible, and solve a few puzzles in the cabin. It's a simple concept but quite atmospheric and enjoyable if you like card based games. By far the best act of this game.

Act 2 is very different and changes into a pixel art style adventure x card battler. I enjoyed this part for the variety of deck builds and lore you can discover, but be aware the game does have some very sharp differences in game play throughout. 

Act 3... I'm still trying to get through it. The game feels like it's overstayed its welcome here as it's a bland, boring hybrid of the previous acts with bad graphics. You can't just push through it as similar to act one, a bad deck draw sends you back a few steps to try again, and again. Not enjoying it at all. 

Still rating as a positive as the first 2 acts are fun. It feels similar to other games by this dev where they're imaginative and have some great atmospheric parts, but other parts get too heavy on the punishing, overly repetitive parts that IMO could have been shortened to increase the overall game enjoyability at the expense of some play time. (I gave up on Pony Island as well which was far, far worse than this game for that aspect and watched a playthrough to see then ending.) Apparently there's a mod you can unlock to get another version of act 1 to play which is the only reason I'd finish it by this point.

So the game wants to tell you the story, and it does that regardless of you having a good "tutorial run" or barely surviving "common" battles. All things that are explained in thetutorial are being explained by the narration of the "game master", the animations are taking ages and you end up hearing the very basics of any roguelite that you most likely already know if you played at least one roguelite/deckbuilder game. On your 3rd/4th run you're able to proceed to act 2 that is just boring and doesn't put up any challenge. In act 3 you're back to relatively the same format of a card game, except that here you don't get strangled when you lose, so you don't start anew but keep all the cards you've gotten so far, only lose your current "robobucks" that you can collect by reaching the chamber you've lost it in. Since your deck does not get reset to the starting one, you may end up with a joke of a deck that loses to the earliest fights in half of the cases. And you only have two options there: farm, get back to the waypoint, replenish your items and get back to the "easiest" encounters, then try to fix your awful deck with some stronger cards (sometimes making it even worse) or just going to the setting and erasing your save files. That's what I did, losing 12 hours of gameplay but slicing through the act 3 as if there was no contest. So I finished the game and got to "Kaycee's mode", which is a roguelite after the story is done. Except that it's considerably weaker than just act 1 and still explains nothing of how the game actually works.

Go get this game just to go through the story but don't expect too much of that roguelike content.

This was my very first card video game (and first ARG) as someone who was never a fan of this genre. I thoroughly enjoyed it and it is now one of my absolute favourites. I can already tell that one day this game will give me nostalgia.
A short review kept as spoiler-free as possible:

PROS:
- atmospheric and immersive
- satisfying game mechanics
- great sound design
- skillfull balance of mystery, emotion, horror and comedy
- so far this game has been a bug-free experience for me and I have played over 36 hours as of now
- being able to play this entirely without a wifi connection has been a lifesaver for me
- my fears of not being able to properly play this due to having a low-end macbook that has been used by T-Rexes as far as its age is concerned, have not come true. Despite its size and complexity this game was wonderfully immersive for me even with low graphic settings and a bad computer setup. The lag I experienced was limited and I was able to enjoy this game to its fullest so far.
- for players who get bored quickly the main storyline of this game offers a lot of variety
- for players who do not like quick change and prefer and a consistent, repetitive experience, the part of the game called 'Kaycee's Mod' (which despite its name is an official part of the game and can be unlocked after completing the main storyline or by pressing a specific key combination in the menu if you're impatient) offers just that, a great challenge system and consistent gameplay

CONS:
- I am sure there are cons but currently I can't think of any, sorry. It's just a fantastic game if this is the kinda stuff you're into

NOTES TO CONSIDER:
- to players who are slow learners some parts of the main story may appear jarring at first. Take your time to fail as often as you need in order to learn, go at your own pace, it is not going to negatively effect your game. I can only give you the advice to keep playing through those experiences, they are intentionally made the way they are and end up enhancing the overall experience immensely. If you feel too stuck, the internet offers a lot of valuable tips for this game (although these often come with spoilers).
- DIALOGUE SPEED CAN BE ADJUSTED IN THE MENU!
- For those who have taken a liking to the first act and find the second and third threw them for a loop I advise you to keep playing anyway in order to get to something called 'Kaycee's Mod' (see points above in PROS)

I hope you consider this game and that it brings you as much joy as it has brought to me.

Before I bought this game, I heard that the less I knew about it before playing it the better. I wish I knew that Inscryption is broken into three parts, and what you see in the advertisements and the front of the Steam page is Part 1. It's the most fun I've ever had with a card game, and the atmosphere was fantastic.

Then Part 2 happens. And it's basically a different game. All the aesthetic elements and roguelike mechanics are gone, and there are additional card mechanics that are more complicated and less fun than what came before. All of this is to serve a meta-narrative that was intriguing at best and disruptive at worst. It feels like Game Theory bait. Part 3 is slightly better but substantially longer and not on the same level as Part 1.

Kaycee's Mod is the main reason Inscryption gets a thumbs up from me.

Pretty fun, especially the first third of the game. It's a decent deckbuilder that's not too punishing. But it also suffers from a lot of weird off-putting stuff and questionable design decisions that just seem unnecessary. Ultimately lacks balance and focus, and tries (weakly, I think) to excuse that as part of the story progression and mechanical evolution.

I don't really understand the comments about forgetting it to play for the first time again, nor the comments about going in blind, nor the comparisons to Outer Wilds. I don't feel like there was much of a story to care about at all, much less any meaningful twists or insights. I do suggest watching the video on the store page and drawing your own conclusions, because the weird stuff in that video reflects a lot about the game. Still maybe worth picking up on sale if you like deckbuilders and want to an unusual experience.

I love a good turn-based card horror game!

The game play is fun if you like the surprise emergent narrative sort of genre (think Undertale, LISA, etc) as well as card games (think Slay the Spire but quite a bit less complex), but a quick word of warning that the game is surprisingly resource intensive for what it is and has a lot of real time graphics and that sort of thing which definitely contribute to the overall experience and atmosphere but also mean the game is much more resource intensive than similar titles in this genre.

I guess I'd phrase it like this: if you're running a PC that's good with AAA or you actually checked the specs then you'll be completely fine, but if you're running a potato and thought to yourself "it's just a card game, how bad can it be?" then I'd recommend you do actually check the official requirements in this case rather than relying on heuristics.

Inscryption is an absolute gem that defies expectations and delivers a gaming experience unlike any other. Its ingenious blend of card-based strategy, cryptic narrative, unexpected twists, and the dark themes surrounding the characters and universe in general kept me hooked from start to finish. The game's unique mechanics, coupled with its atmospheric design and compelling storytelling, make it probably one of my top, if not favourite indie games I've ever played.
I never expected Inscryption to be much, much deeper than just the card-builder game it's advertised as, but it truly takes you on a trip like none other.
If you enjoy card-builder games, and are looking for something different, Inscryption will exceed your expectations.

An incredible game that I would highly recommend if you like card-games, puzzles and mysteries. Some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Amazing atmosphere
- The storytelling is a lot of fun. Its funny, creepy and dramatic at the same time. Its like a modern fairy tale, which I think was the aim of the story.
- The game is well-balanced. If you have some experience with card-games you can easily get through. If you don't, the learning curve is not very steep.
- Lots of replayability. The free "Kacey's Mod" DLC is a excellent.
- That ending... wow.

Cons:
- Although the story and visual reveals at Act II and Act III will blow your mind, they are a lot weaker in terms of gameplay.
- Act III, in particular, can be a bit of a slog to get through. Trust me: its worth it for the ending. And the bosses in Act III are the best in the game, in my opinion.

All in all, highly recommended

Inscryption is hard to describe. If you enjoy deck-building games with simple mechanics but lots of variation and lots of curve balls being thrown at you, you will enjoy this game. The atmosphere is dark, with lots of messed up stuff going on around you, and there is a fun story too, so there is lots to keep you playing. The less you know the better, so if that description appeals to you, then get it.

If you are thinking of not getting it because that description is not up your alley, then let me give you some MILD SPOILERS to describe why this game isn't just good, its great.

[spoiler] The game is will constantly surprise you. No really. As soon as you think you have figured it out, it pulls the rug out from under you. I cannot adequately describe how meta the game is and how much the game changes as you as play. Not into card battlers? While it is big part of the game, the real draw is the story, mystery angle you find several hours in. The actual game mechanics are easy to master, its just a matter of thinking and learning as things are given to you, so even if this description is not normally the sort of you game you play, power through it because its not the real core of the game and it is actually pretty easy to get laughably good at this game. [/spoiler]

Bottom line, don't research this game, don't spoil anymore than what I have written here, just get it and let it take you for a ride.

Not only are the story, ambiance, music, and characters fantastic, but I enjoy gameplay so much that I rarely find myself frustrated when I die, because it just means I get to play everything all over again.

This is only a card game some of the time, it's only a roguelite some of the time. This is a story driven game that uses the roguelite and cardgame bits of the narrative to further the plot. That 's not to say the gameplay is bad, at it's heart this is a psychological horror/puzzle game that keeps you on your toes. Without spoiling it, you think the first act is the entire game loop and then the game gets 4x bigger in terms of mechanics and the mechanics keep evolving, there's even a 5 minute section where they riff on Yugioh in the coolest way possible and honestly, I need more. The card game is so well designed and I wish it was fleshed out into a full TCG or DBG. I cannot recommend this more highly if you enjoy the post "StS" glut of "Roguelite deck builders" the card game mechanics here are so good and original and it keeps you engaged all the way through, there was never a moment like I felt like I was repeating myself. even in failure. There is so much to do and explore outside of the card game matches that it just never gets stale.

This game is a unique experience. The deckbuilding elements can be expanded by solving some puzzles, and every failed run let's you make a combo card out of the stuff you picked up that run. Some interactions aren't pointed out, but if you discover them, they change the game. Some cards have utility based on what the card represents, rather than the numbers or abilities.

And for sure start a new game after you beat Leshy, it's a whole new experience, and you'll be better prepared for the challenges you'll face.

How far can you get before you die and get insult added to injury. That's the game. The post losing portion takes so long and is so disheartening that I don't even have any interest in starting again because I know I won't be able to win and I will have to do it all over again and I know that after that play-through I won't be able to win either and will have to do it all over again and after about 6 or 7 losses my zeal for the game is so crumpled up an jaded that I can't be bothered to try again. 

The game is intentionally rigged against you from the start. You don't even get taught all the basic tutorial stuff at the beginning you have to lose multiple times to even unlock the rest of the tutorial and by that time you have had to watch the 'you lose' portion like three times at least. 
I hate developers that make failing an unavoidable mechanic of the game. It's like, "haha you lost, now please put a label on your loss so that it can be flung in your face every time that you play after this time."

Otherwise the gameplay is bland and dull the card battles are setup where you either win immediately or lose immediately and they are over so quickly that it's almost pointless to start one because as soon as you actually start getting into it it's already over. You get cards that require you to put down like 3 sacrifice cards to be able to play them and getting more than one sacrifice card down at a time is difficult and 2-3 of them is more or less impossible and if you are able to get that many down at one time then the cards you are going against are so weak that it's pointless to put that much effort in in the first place.

This game is great! It starts looking like an interesting card game only to quickly evolve into an intriguing and eerie story. The greatest aspects of the game only become apparent once you've completed what I'd call Act I. It leads you to believe that the game will reach its climax, but instead greets you with a new challenge as you struggle to balance new mechanics and build an effective deck. By the end of Act II you'll find yourself piecing together a greater story that is continued in Act III. Act III starts by looking like just another round of the game you'd find at the beginning of Act I (with a couple small twists). You will quickly find that this is not the case, as the developers ensure that you do not feel as though your time was wasted by making you rebuild yet another new deck. You will feel that the momentum continues to build through Act III and by the end it leaves you empathetic to those you initially blamed for your predicament. Ultimately, this is a great game that will keep you entertained for hours and gives you a story worth embracing!

This game is deeply astonishing.
I myself am a huge fan of deck builder games, this however is a whole other level!
In the beginning you are obviously confused of why you're not able to start a new game. Thus the mystery commences! Continuously intruding your thoughts on what is going on.
I really like the way foreshadowing is used in the little snippets with The Lucky Carder and the way everything unfolds later on just feels right.
But even if you don't focus on the story, this game is still lovely. I could spend hours playing without adressing the story and when I read the files of Kaycee in the mod expansion, I could relate so much to what was being expressed.
Especially the way I was able to upgrade my cards was of interest to me, unfolding almost an unlimited amount of possible combinations to make your deck perfect. Sometimes I would just try to achieve a single card combination to test it out on the battlefield.

TL;DR:
Great deck builder game you can play if you...
1. want to dive head first into a mystery
2. want something you can play with ease while watching or listening to something
3. like games with multiple layers
4. like deck building or card collecting games

Update: I still love this game!

Inscryption opens with MASTERPIECE level quality. The sound design, graphic design, and general vibe are INCREDIBLE, and the game master is one of the coolest game villains of all time. 

[spoiler]The gimmick is cool, but the constant plot twists later in the game really started to be predictable and detract from the overall experience for me. The intentionally campy camcorder videos also ended up spoiling the impeccable vibe more than being funny. 

Later problems aside, the beginning of [/spoiler]this game is worth full price. Seriously, SO GOOD.

This game is both hard, yet it's fun and let's you do (within some rules) whatever you'd like. 
Act 1: Want a Deathcard that is a Free 7/7 that flies, grows stronger after 1 turn, and makes chimes that if destroyed, this card will swing to that lane? go ahead.
Act 2: Discover an infinite? You're rich, sonny!
Act 3: Remember making that Deathcard? Let's let you make AND have MULTIPLE of these cards by trading in any card you want! also your fooling around in Act 2 gets you an appearance of the Bone Lord and a Mycologist Boss Battle!
Kaycee's Mod: What comes to someone's mind when presented with a custom challenge mode? if you said "crank everything to the hardest setting," you're right on the money. even besides that, this post game is a full-on upgrade to Act 1 to further it as a Rougelike game, adding plenty of things that were not in Act 1, where the story is taking the back seat. sure, there's no deathcards and you have to unlock the extra cards, most of the challenges, and most Starter Decks, but it helps fuel a sense of progress.
missed a Main Story Achievement? simply go back to any of five points of the story (Start of Act 1, End of Act 1, Start of Act 2, Start of Act 3, and right before the Great Transendance)
Want to use mods? just like any great game, there's plenty of mods to suit your liking, Wanna play with Plants Vs Zombies characters, go ahead, Act 1 if Grimora was in control? Already ahead of you. Give this game a shot. It's worth the $20 and goes on sale somewhat frequently for half off if you lack $20 but have $10.

Oh this game is a blast! It's a first person card/puzzle game that's full of surprises and twists and more puzzles. It's all the best features of MTG, Myst, and escape rooms... all combined into a neat and tidy game. The story is wild. The development is better than what Steven King could think up, and the world is detailed in the right ways without being too cumbersome.
The best part IMO is that parts of the gameplay dynamic are broken in YOUR FAVOR. You can create combinations that are wildly to your advantage, but ultimately don't change the game negatively. You still experience the same robust story, you just get to do it in an overpowered way... Sometimes. And sometimes your overpowered glitched cards don't help at all! It's so much fun. Give it a try.
If you ever said to yourself "What Slay the Spire was really missing, was first person Resident Evil Puzzles." then boy howdy should you check this out.

I was initially drawn to this game by its art direction, as seen in the trailers. 

When I found out that it was a card-based game, I was even more intrigued. To my surprise, I had an incredibly enjoyable experience playing it, and it has become one of my favorite games of the year. 

I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a new game to try!

I'll try and be concise.

This game has several chapters. The vast majority of the videos we see here and there show the chapter 1, even all screenshots on this page are from chapter 1.

Now... I don't like card games, and I don't like 8-bits games.
BUT, what I saw in trailer was quite interesting, so I gave it a try.

And I really enjoyed chapter one.
But then... chapter 2... and it is not the same game at all. I don't play 8-bits usually because I can't see or read what's displayed in those quite easily. Chapter two takes away the nice graphics, switching you from first person to 2D crawler style, cards are ugly and almost un-readable to me... not the same game AT ALL.

At first, I wanted to give a positive review nonetheless, but, it feels to me that it is false advertising, plain and simple. It is a good game if you like the genre(s)... But seing how rare, everywhere, the images of chapters 2 and 3 are... I can't shake the feeling there is foul play here. So for me, the game ends at chapter 1, frustrated.

Quite honestly one of THE most mesmerizing games I've ever played.
I'm really picky when it comes to card games, I love card games but I am easily turned off by a lot of factors.
Inscryption was quite the gamble for me, it will either be a hit or miss, no in-between.
And man, oh man, what I have to say is that this is MORE than a "Hit" could ever be.

Coming into this game, not knowing fully well what this game truly is, even thinking it'd be heavily leaning on the horror, while it certainly is, this game is SO SO SO SO SO much more than that, like actually legitimately.
This game goes beyond one's expectations, it tricks you, it lures you in, it's just so god damn captivating.
It isn't even a game anymore at this point, it's closer to a full-on film, but before that, one could even say it is an all-out experience.

The game is absolutely AMAZING, this is a big statement to say but I personally think this is THE best card game you'll ever find out there.

It isn't too flashy, bomboarded with graphics and designs, it's simple, yet beautiful, it immerses you into it with your own cards and characters, all-the-while never feeling bland, dull, or boring. The story, god, don't even get me started on it, if you love games like Undertale, DDLC, IMSCARED or such alike, please, I beg of you, PLEASE do play this game.
I cannot express enough just how many times this game had surprised me, shocked me, just, outright made me enjoy it over and over and over and over again, like one after another it hits you with something absolutely amazing, something absolutely wild, this game never gets old, no matter how long you play it, you just feel like you want to play more and more and more.

What I so love about this game is that how the actual game itself genuinely DOES have a story, and you always feel like you actually ARE going somewhere, you feel like there actually is a direction to everything you do even with the fact you aren't sure of it, or if you aren't aware, or even if you are flat out lost.

Even if you fail or be unable to beat something, it's instantly rewarded with something amazing right after, that always encapsulates you more and more into the game, the replayability of this game is truly endless.

I can't think of a game that would fit the criteria for both card game lovers and non-card game lovers, a game that would fit for both horror game lovers and even non-horror game lovers, hell, or even a game for people who want a story to the game, or just flat-out arcadey-esque fun.

This game has everything, absolutely everything, and I love each and every single second that I have spent my time on this game.

I plan on continuing this game sometime soon and perfecting honestly, it deserves every single penny in full price, and honestly, without a shadow of doubt, even more.

This is one of the best games I've ever played, period.

[h1]Introduction[/h1] 
[b]Inscryption[/b] is a collectible card game with unique mechanics mixed in with some horror elements.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Unique creepy visual style
+ Great gameplay variety
+ Fun hardcode mode

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Can feel unfair at times
- Mystries are unraveled way too soon

[h1]Story[/h1]
In the dense forest devoid of any light and roamed by scary beasts, there's a wooden cabin, where you're being held prisoner. Your captor generously offers you a game of cards; the rules are simple, and the stakes are your life. 

With this simple premise, the game manages to tell a pretty interesting story. Between the rounds of playing cards, you can get up from the table and look around the cabin. Discovering all of its mysteries and figuring out a way home takes a keen eye and a sharp mind. However, after around one-third of the game most of the mysteries are unraveled and the story becomes more straightforward and less obscure. It's hard to talk about it without venturing into spoiler territory. So, I guess I'll leave it at that to not spoil your experience.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Most reviewers say that you're supposed to go into this game blind, but I respectfully disagree with this viewpoint. I won't go into detail here, just in case you might consider this a spolier. Nonetheless, it's worth noting that for the most part of the game (around 90 percent I'd say), it uses collectible card game mechanics. Which means that you have to manage a deck of cards with various abilities and make use of their combinations in order to win. So, you should be aware of it before buying the game.

If you like this type of gameplay, then you'd probably love this game. It introduces a multitude of unique mechanics, I haven't seen in other similar games. Furthermore, [b]Inscryption[/b] also mixes up its formula so often, that you always have to learn new mechanics and synergies. Since the game isn't a multiplayer one, it doesn't have to deal with the balance issues so much. Because of that you can create some heavily overpowered decks, that will mow down every opponent in just a couple of turns. After completing the game you will also unlock a hardcore mode, that focuses on the battle mechanics and really puts your deck-building skills to the test.

[h1]Graphics & Audio[/h1]
Technically the game's visuals are nothing impressive, but the low-poly style can invoke nostalgia for PS1-era games. The lighting makes a great job at hiding technical imperfections of low-poly 3D models and highlighting the most important parts, that will let your imagination fill in the blanks. The soundtrack creates a tense atmosphere, that lets you feel the high stakes of each battle. Sound effects are also top notch, interacting with the game's world gives off this strange tactile pleasure. 

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Specs: AMD Ryzen 9 5900HX, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 Laptop GPU 8GB, 32GB RAM.

The game runs at 165 FPS in 1080p at max graphical settings. There were no crashes or other technical issues with the game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Inscryption[/b] is an interesting take on a collectible card game genre, that can surprise even the ones who played a lot of the recent similar games. The story is also engaging even though it shows its hand way too soon. If you're a fan of card-based games or a fan of horror mysteries, I highly recommend this game.

Do yourself a favor and give it a shot, I don't think you'll regret it.

Absolutely stunning. Highly Highly recommend to anyone who desires an immersive and compelling video game experience. The visuals are gorgeous and incredibly unique, and the sound design makes everything feel so visceral. I went into this with zero deck-building/card game experience and was able to grasp the mechanics fairly easily, so don't let that deter you from giving this game a try. Plus, it has great replay value with both the base game and Kaycee's Mod.

Video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oSrGoZJ30qw

Inscryption is actually a deck building horror game, and it's absolutely incredible. This is not a game you want to be spoiled for.

We play as Luke Carder (Kevin Saxby), an enthusiastic card gamer and content creator. Luke comes into possession of a mysterious unrecognizable game called Inscryption. Luke plays the game and there is clearly something evil about it. In the game itself there are three separate card games with their own unique mechanics and boss fights, each sharing the same characters as each utmost notably the four Scrybes, who are sort of the Gods of this universe.

Inscryption is a mind blowing experience to be honest. The story is crafted with such love and it's genuinely really interesting every single moment you are playing. The mechanics are surprisingly well put together despite the primary focus being it's captivating mystery. The horror elements are also unexpected considering it's a deck building game, but they are effective and the art and visuals, and the overall eeriness of the situations you find yourself in make it a great horror experience too.

The characters were very memorable and I especially liked the talking cards who would react to your decisions. The premise is strong and would inspire others like it in the future, such as the Netflix film "Choose or Die" (2022). I would have been satisfied with just the first act of the game, but it goes the extra mile and creates full on entirely different games to play afterwards. My only criticisms are how busted and game breaking Ouroboros is (Although this was definitely intended, but I still don't like it), and the cringey acting from Kevin Saxby which kind of killed the tension and atmosphere the game was establishing.

Inscryption is a must play even if you don't personally fancy deck building card games. There is a myriad of secrets to be found here and the lore is clearly very in-depth and intriguing.

10/10.
