an underrated hidden Gem. On the surface it just looks like your typical card strategy game , on the surface this is true ; however , there is this whole sinister plot and subplot hidden alongside that which gets revealed as you play and progress , even some things you may miss if you aren't very thorough or following a guide. So 10 / 10 would recommend though i will say certain sections can be highly challenging and will rely on luck whether it be your dray or your current AI opponents and their move. To mix things up the way the game is played changes as you enter later Arc's due to each unique character who's cards and style's are different than Leshy's who we are first introduced to. I'm curious as to what kind of decks others had and stuck with by the end-game , me my deck was a mix but primarily beast cards like the start of the game aside from the parts where you really need to use the other card types or have only those types. But there is no one ' Meta ' and good cards and combinations from each card type so there are many different ways to play. However , you may find yourself choosing some cards over others just due to your current need despite wanting others due to particularly difficult bosses you may be facing at the time. The best way to put it is there are highly situational factors as with any strategy game.

adding this part at the end with spoiler tags for anyone that doesn't already know and wants it to be a surprise. [spoiler]There is even one specific boss where you get to make and give a card to another player and bless them with something highly useful like i did or curse them with something useless. Also this same boss is a multiple parter , if no one is playing you fight the AI but if someone is playing at the same time as you , you end up having to face them and the winner gets to progress. To end things off , the game is designed to only be played once , and who you get matched with is completely random. But if you and a friend were to play that part at the same time there is a slim chance you may get matched with one another.[/spoiler]

It's hard to describe Inscryption in one go because of how well it defies limits and expectations. It has a deeply engaging story that becomes even more fascinating as things unravel, and its hand-carved atmosphere blends well with the characters, the cards and the narrative. This is a rabbit-hole kind of game and certainly one of the freshest and most impactful horror games I've played in a long time. It's ingenuity unleashed; a rare sort of experience that's daring and layered with a quality type of darkness you won't soon forget.

Gameplay-wise, it's challenging but not too unforgiving. It borrows (and subverts) a few mechanics from games like MTG but Inscryption is very much its own thing. And just like Slay The Spire (and another card video game I'd like to mention but can't because of spoilers), the D&D-like progression is both balanced and engaging. The various visuals and fitting soundtrack mixed with a solid gameplay loop make for a satisfying and tense experience.

I'd like to say more but I'd be getting into spoiler territory. This is a great game with a lot of thought and imagination behind it. It's equal parts fun, harrowing and engrossing. If this sounds like your jam then I highly recommend giving Inscryption a shot.

If you are interested in what's shown on the store page, just know that there's a lot more to the game than just that. It builds on itself a lot so things will change but also be pretty familiar. You may not vibe with a section here or there but it's worth it to keep playing. The game isn't too long and is divided up into three main acts. Lots of people are not big fans of act 2, and I wasn't at first. Once I got the hang of it though I warmed up to it. The game does its best to nudge you in the right direction to proceed, but you can get stuck in a couple spots not knowing what to do. If you're not sure what to do, stand up and walk around, there might be something you can do now, or you didn't realize you could do something with it until now. It's always worth double checking all the objects around you to see if there's something you missed.

I didn't fly into this game blind; I watched ManlyBadassHero's playthrough some time back, so I knew what to expect. But even still, the game is highly captivating and charming to play through. It's challenging as hell, I'm not gonna lie. Especially once you touch the Kaycee's Mod side of things (that skull storm achievement was hell and I think I hate bears now lol). But it's equally rewarding, and suuuuper fun to make really busted card combinations.

Inscyption is very much a "if at first you don't succeed: die, die again" kind of game. Every failed run is a learning experience and it - as well as exploration - will ensure you're a bit better prepared and equipped for your next run. So don't be discouraged if you fail a few runs; it's all part of the progression. :] In saying that, I would suggest holding off on touching Kaycee's Mod until you've completed the main story; both for lore reasons, and so you have a better, broader, understanding of how your cards, sigils, items, and totems work. It'll make things a bit easier and a smidge less aggravating. Because you will die a *lot* more in that than in the main game, thanks to the challenge modifiers. I adore the final boss that replaces Leshy, [spoiler]Royal.[/spoiler] Real vibrant personality; made the fight a legitimately fun experience to go through.

It reminds me of Sally Face A LOT: story-wise and feeling-wise. First you feel mystery and really enjoy the game and you are eager to see more. But then...its just all over the place :o Its like if you are listening to nice sounding metal song and then it suddenly turns into rap-song, and then into classical and then goes back to metal for 2 seconds and then some worlds biggest orchestral masterpiece or something and at the same time there is commercial voice talking in background+ elevator music. After hearing that "Confusing Song" you are just left with a bitter taste in your mouth. Like: "Why would you do that to your nice metal song? The beginning was really good!" Thats the feeling of Inscryption. Sometimes less is more.

It's all too easy to overlook this game being a deck builder/card battle game at its core with the way it presents itself. Spooky and disturbing (but not too much) at times, it's also an ultimately... Cozy experience. 
Art direction and sound design are top notch as the game does its best to immerse you in its bizzare atmosphere, offering limited exploration akin to early 90s 3D point and click games with their crude and limited yet surreal and fascinating visuals, and card battles, including boss fights, presented as  immersive theatrical spectacles. And it's definitely not all style over substance - there are secrets to discover to the story that's unwrapping right in front of your eyes. The game also pays great attention to details, bringing something new to the table every time you decide to have another go at it. As far as card battles go, you're at RNG mercy, so it all comes down to luck, which, I think, fits the overall style of the game perfectly.

I would never expect such a satisfying card game based with solid story. Absolutely amazed me and some moments managed to make me emotionally sad near the end game.
Whenever i thought "okay looks like this is all how it works" the game brings in new dynamics into the story to change the perspective, style and even humor.

My one and only criticism is P03 (robot) chapter has cold colored design that makes difficult to focus deck play which made me bored time to time.

By the way this price is a real steal, so thank you so much for everything (:

This game is a very unique experience. I've been playing mtg for 20ish years so i tend to like deck building games in general (i.e. slay the spire, hearthstone, etc) but this game is awesome imo. the game has three distinct 'acts', the game evolves drastically after 20+ hours of gameplay, and does that again after about another 10-20 hours, into a third act where the game has reached its most sophisticated state, where you'll find about another 10-20 hours worth.

***there is a mandatory escape-room side-quest/over-world thing that must be completed before you can progress out of act 1: this was not my favorite component to the game but it does have a contribution to the game on the whole.

in this game the core mechanics that you learn in the first act are built on gradually throughout each act and then slightly morphed in the next act, but the skills, card knowledge, and strategies you have been learning are relevant throughout every act.

I beat this game over the course of a long weekend some months ago, and since then I have been looking forward for enough time to pass for me to play through again.

A fantastic game 80% of the time. The art direction, music and sound design are phenomenal. The gameplay in Act 1; trying to juggle between board space and eliminating enemy threats is great, this in-depth system allows you to experience different synergies. At times it feels more like a puzzle than a card game.
The second and third acts, while not bad, are too easy and boring.
As for the Roguelike mode, [spoiler] Kaycee's Mod [/spoiler], it starts off great, introduces new cards, sigils, threats and modifiers, getting progressively harder, BUT if you want to beat the highest difficulty (Skull Storm) it's mostly comes down to RNG (there are ways to manipulate RNG, but if you lack the right cards and buffs on them, it will lead to an insta-loss in [spoiler] GrizzlyBosses BearRush [/spoiler]), the last Boss is great tho.
It's worth playing.

I've got some very mixed feelings about inscryption as I usually do for my favorite games. So my TL;DR is this: buy this game if you're interested in it but be prepared for some meh parts. It's mostly a very unique and fun experience that you'll walk away from wanting a sequel. You'll also get a ton of hours of gameplay out of it and it's free 'DLC'.

and now, here's my nitpicky "I sunk too many hours into this game and this is what I think".

Inscryption presents itself as a VERY engaging game with a promise of mystery and secrets. The cardplay is solid, it's a great introduction to deckbuilding games even if you don't particularly like the genre. The atmosphere is immersive*, the artstyle is super unique and nice to look at, and it's one of those games leaving you wanting for more.

... and then that all kinda starts falling apart as it goes on. Inscryption has a LOT of big ideas that, in my opinion, never got the space to become fully realized. They crammed a *ton* into it, and while usually I'd applaud that at times it felt like the story was getting in the way of gameplay. This game really loves to juxtapose fantasy with reality and while I understand it was a purposeful choice I found myself unable to suspend my disbelief for both concepts. 

I REALLY wish they would have stuck with something simpler because the quality of the game and the atmosphere is through the roof fantastic. The story of it all really just was not my cup of tea. I felt a very 'been there done that' kind of emotion for a game so outwardly unique as Inscryption is.

I digress, it feels seriously criminal to not recommend this game with how much I've enjoyed it. Everything about the gameplay down to the little sounds each object makes is immensely satisfying. They didn't miss a single time with the soundtrack either, every song is perfect for when it's played. It's definitely one of those hidden gems that just feels super nice to interact with because the dev took their time with things. [spoiler] And despite what people say about Act 1 being the best, I found myself really enjoying Act 3 and wishing that that too got it's own 'Kacyee's mod treatment'. [/spoiler]. Overall, I'm excited to see what this dev goes on to create.

So with all of that said, I would buy this game again at full price. You know when you spend twenty bucks on a game and come out with 90 hours in it that you've made a good purchase. You just... gotta be prepared to give it some grace in certain moments. You'll know them when you see them.

Inscryption is a game about card games as much as it is a card game itself. Some people prefer the pure roguelike aspect of the first act (which is why Kaycee's mod exists and is so popular nowadays), but I found the narrative and atmosphere to be quite gripping throughout all three acts. I'll keep my thoughts on the story vague since uncovering the mysteries is a big part of the fun, but the recent Hard Drive article about this being a game that your friends won't shut up about telling you to play it while refusing to tell you anything is right on the money, and for good reason.

Update, Still great

A lot of the negative reviews say something like "I loved the first act but hated the rest". I guess I'm in the ultra-minority of not even thinking the first act is that great and the game coasts by on vibes instead of gameplay.

It is a very sub-par deckbuilder. You have essentially the same starting deck each time. Nothing like Slay the Spire's 4 characters, or Monster Train's 5 clans. Boss battles have the annoying tendency to introduce unique mechanics you've never seen before, almost guaranteeing you fail the first time. You fight the same three bosses every time, there's no variety. The actual game mechanics are very simplistic. Basically all you can do is summon creatures. There's no buffing, debuffing, instant effects, on-going effects, or anything else. Summon a creature to one of four lanes and then watch it auto-battle each turn until something dies.

The way the game does balance & difficulty just feels unsatisfying. You have to beat the boss twice, usually with some kind of board reset/wipe in between. I know giving the boss more health than you have is almost universal but I hate the "you've killed the boss but they just revive with full hit points" approach to it. It also suffers from the same problem other narrative-heavy roguelikes (like Sunless Sea) have. Nobody is interested in your dialogue after they've read 5 or 10 or 20 times. Why do I have to click 3 or 4 times to get out of the campfire or the trapper or whatever else?

But also, yeah, the second act is even worse. It adds more cards and styles of play to the deckbuilding (finally!) but changes almost everything else about the game, including the rogue-like aspect. So you don't even "progress" when you lose a battle and die. You just try, try, try again hoping for a better RNG. Also, a weird drop to 8-bit pixel graphics.

The game got so caught up being a 3rd year student's art project that it under-delivers on the actual game mechanics.

Easily one of the most annoying games I've ever played. Extreme RNG dependence, long useless cutscenes, annoying slow unskippable dialogue throughout, no explanations for what things do, everything you have to look up online. The premise is even worse, being trapped in a cabin you must escape from. What makes me so mad is that this game could easily have been tons of fun if all the excess fluff wasn't there slowing everything down and confusing you. But then, combat is so luck dependent on the right draws or having the right items that the deckbuilding aspect isn't that fun. You're forced to add bad cards to your deck, forced to click through hundreds of useless dialogues every run, forced to look up what cards do online. It's like it was designed by a brilliant game savant and then remade by his idiot cousin with no concept of why the game was good in the first place.

Inscryption starts out with an intriguing premise - a horror-themed card game with a player stuck in a cabin (presumably, in the woods). The first act is fun - a mixture of deck-building, exploring and puzzle solving, before you move into a SNES version of the game, then a more modern feel, while a Blair Witch-style video plays out, giving an overall plot to what you're doing. Unfortunately, the second act is merely ok, and the third act is a tiresome mix of overly complex mechanics and a plot that you feel less and less connected with, before a finale that (by this time) feels like it's just gotten carried away with itself and is being overly mysterious for the sake of it, a bit like a thespian friend who gets carried away and should have stopped with the first act, rather than getting deeper and deeper into something that feels less and less satisfying. Good value in a steam sale, otherwise ... meh.
10/10. WORTH A BUY AT FULL PRICE!!!

Okay. Okay. Okay.
If you don't want any spoilers (or, for some reason, the idea of reading a small essay where someone vents about Inscryption is unappealing to you) then you can go ahead and play the game. Just do it. There's a good forty hours of fun packed into this brilliant, masterful...
deeply unfinished game.
Okay spoilers ahead.
It. Is. Not. Finished. The story has no end. The plot is never resolved. All of your favorite characters die and you can do nothing but watch. You will never learn what the OLD_DATA is. The only person who gets to do that is Luke, the awful, annoying dude who does nothing at all for the story but is the only one who gets to see how it ends. Acts I, II and III are the setup for an absolutely killer Act IV, but there is none. There is only Kaycee's mod, a mildly fun twist on the game you were already playing, which allows you to unlock development logs, which DON'T resolve the story you were invested in but DO gradually reveal a confusing, unrelated B-plot about the old data being codes to blow up Berlin? What? That can't be it. Why on Earth would any of the Scrybes care if some city in a world they don't live in blows up? Furthermore, why would Luke go insane and try to smash the game with a hammer from being told that?  Does he have any reason to think it's real? And what does ANY of this have to do with the world of Inscryption, the world I was incredibly eager to learn all I could about? All it does is bring the total number of people who get to see the real ending when you don't up to two...You had me, Daniel Mullins Games! I swallowed your game hook, line and sinker! I was absolutely blown away by the writing, by the love and care you put into the game. There are three different sections, each with entirely different, brilliant graphics! The characters are awesome and the writing is so good you got me to feel for the guy who spent a very long time killing me again and again.
I saw a vision of a perfect world. One where all that setup led to an act where I discovered what the old data really was‚Äîmaybe it's the force that created the world of Inscryption in the first place, or the thing that traps the scrybes and their servants in the endless cycle of death and torture. One where I got to play Grimora and Manificus's version of the game, where I got to rescue my favorite characters from their horrible fates and restore Inscryption to its glory. Or at least tell the lonely wizard that I would literally die for him. One where I maybe even got to take my place as a Scrybe, one where the metastory of the game focused on ME, instead of that horrible Luke.
Oh no. Is it time to rant about Luke?
Do you want to know the one moment of the game that utterly broke my suspension of disbelief? The moment when the woman who showed up at Luke's door claimed she was a fan of his channel.
Guys. He's so boring. He's a terrible youtuber. His card-cracking videos are just him being like. "This is a deck of a game. This is one card that was in the deck. It's not terrible. Next pack...." I cheered aloud when he was shot, because I thought that maybe, FINALLY, I was going to get to play the game as myself, instead of being shoved aside so somebody I don't like can take credit for everything I do and the characters can form bonds with him instead of me. And what kills me is that they could have so easily just cut him out entirely and had the characters address you by name (OneShot-style) because his story adds literally nothing of value to the gameplay. He does NOTHING to influence the story and is only there so he can spookily dig up the game out of the woods, spookily pile dice onto a scale, and spookily get shot by a forever unidentified lady in shades. Tell me, Daniel Mullins, why did you think I would enjoy the game more if I wasn't the one playing it? 
I'm definitely going to replay the game, and I'm definitely going to skip the ending. And I'm going to spend the rest of my life mourning Grimora and Leshy and my dear, beloved Lonely Wiz, and dearly wishing their stories had been seen to a satisfying end.
For the love of god, Daniel Mullins Games, if you release a DLC with an act IV I will buy it literally no matter how much it costs.
That's the end of that. I'm going to go cry now.

There are spoilers below.

- I enjoyed 49.9% of this game.
- I strongly disliked 50.1% of this game.

Some of the things that I don't like might be things that you like, so you may still want to get the game.

DISCLAIMER
I am a 51 year old female.
I don't like puzzles unless they are easy to figure out.
I am new to card games like this.
My only card game experience has been Slay the Spire.

I probably don't play games in the same way that most do.
I like to go through the game and have it not be too hard.
I enjoy seeing the art of the new creatures, etc. that are introduced as you play.
Appearance and aesthetics matter to me.

I downloaded a mod because Slay the Spire was way too hard and I wanted to see the creatures and go through the story. I loved Slay the Spire with the mod, but did not like it without it.

I am old and I don't want to spend nine years to 'git gud' as you may now be thinking of writing me.

I do not fully understand what 'Roguelike' means, but I think it means you die and go back to the beginning. If that definition is correct, I do not like that aspect of roguelike. 
I would like to be able to make game saves so I can go to a point and play with those cards again.

I am old and don't want to spend nine years playing through the same level and same creatures because my character died 9,678 times.

Tldr ‚Äì I am a card game noob and like shiny things.

DISCLAIMER COMPLETE

ACT 1

GAMEPLAY - PUZZLES
I liked a few of the puzzles, but was completely annoyed by others. 
They were too hard to figure out. 
Sometimes, using a guide was still difficult.

APPEARANCE
It looked generally good.
I know it was supposed to be horror, but I thought it was a little too dark - more light could have been added to the scenes.

GAMEPLAY
It was somewhat easy to learn the rules of the cards, but it was too hard for me.
I had to have help to beat one of the bosses.

GAMEPLAY ‚Äì MAP
I need tool tips!

I had to play with a separate screen open with the icons explained, because the icons were so cryptic and I still don't know what most of them mean.

There were a lot of things that were confusing to me.
I never figured them out until I had help.

I liked the creativity of the game in how they combined different things - the 3D and the video - but the story was too fragmented, so it took away from the creativity.

ACT 2

APPEARANCE
At first, I was not as horrified as others by the change in the look.
It looked...hmm...'good' for what it was supposed to be, even though it was a different universe of appearance from Act 1.
As good as that style can look, but not very interesting to my eyes.
but...

LENGTH
It was too long.
This would have been okay if it was for about five minutes as a link to go to the next act.
My eyes were not happy looking at that style for so long.

GAMEPLAY
I did not like the additional mechanics that were introduced. It was confusing and I had no idea what something was supposed to do. Also having all those cards would make the few gem cards I had meaningless, etc. 
The fights were easy enough that this did not matter.

I had fun fighting the dummy and overpowering my ouroboros.

I was not upset about this. It is an observation: 0% of this was scary.
It was cute.
If you wanted this for horror, you will not like Act 2 Cuteland.

ACT 3

GAMEPLAY - MAP: 
Walking around this map was incredibly irritating.
I had to have a huge map open on another screen because if I did not, I kept going back to the same place or getting lost.
A tiny map on screen so I could tell where I was would have been helpful.

APPEARANCE
The appearance of this map and its contents was not good.
Everything had lines through it and was like a ghost. Like an old TV display that was going bad.
I was squinting the entire time I was on the map and it strained my eyes.

Traveling through this map after my 9,678 deaths was painful.
I hope to never again visit this map or anything like it.

The fight scenes were back to 3D and this was fine, but still too dark like Act 1.

GAMEPLAY ‚Äì MONEY/MAP
Every time you die, your money goes into a bag and you have to find where it was left. Due to my map-following issues, I was annoyed trying to find it. This might be easier for males who usually have a better sense of direction than females due to their inherited abilities from being hunters in ancient times.

If you had a lot of money, you had to sit and watch a counter for what seemed like nine years as it rolled to zero. The same thing happens when you pick up the money! 
Since I died  9,678 times trying to get by this one boss mechanic, I spent nine years walking back through the ugly maze and then waiting another nine years for the money to get picked up!
Fabulously irritating. 
Please, just show the amount for a second!

GAMEPLAY
I never saw the hammer and played most of the third act without it, contributing to my 9,678 deaths.

Three minutes before game end...So cool! I can now make my own cards!
Wait! Now the game is over and I can't make them anymore!

ENDING
I did not like the ending.
It just seemed like a waste of time as I played games I could not lose.
The story was not completed.

Leshy and my OP ouroboros were the only interesting characters.
I forgot all the rest.
If you are going to have a story with characters, then take some time to make them interesting.

Heroically, I tried to start again thinking maybe something would be easier or I would have my old cards or something would be new and interesting, but no.
Back to the same cryptic map icons and bad starting cards, and I am done.

I LOVE this game. Inscryption is addicting with its highly dynamic, easy to understand, hard to master gameplay. It is also perfect for those times when you have 15 to 30 minute intervals to play a game.

I am now looking to the community for more content, there are a lot of mods out there which flesh out the game more. Card games may not be your forte (it isn't mine either), but this game was able to get me hooked very quickly. Heavily recommend this game to anyone looking for a good strategy  "think things through" type game. It is just a shame that there isn't any official merch.

I split this review into four sections, and will judge each section according to my initial reactions. I will be as brutally honest as I was when I first experienced them long ago. I also replayed the game to make sure that my criticisms were still valid, so I will be taking that into account:
Act 1:
Act 1 is the delight that I was hoping it was going to be. I played the demo and was absolutely thrilled to see that it was everything promised and more. The difficulty is quite nice, but with recent updates, can be utterly shattered. Additionally, the requirement of a death after victory to beat the cabin puzzles is a bit cruel to someone who is replaying the game with the knowledge and skill that comes with it. All-in-all, great first time but poor replay ability unless you're intentionally bad at the game. The only critique I had on my first run through was that I had to replay the demo, but a small critique given the overall quality.
Act 2:
Absolutely my style, and I loved evrey minute of it. I loved the secrets, the style, the feel, and even the absolute terror you can cause with the legendary Oroborus! Sadly.... I didn't find any of these on my first run through. I didn't get the game breaking Oroborus, nor the obelisk, nor the Mycologist (because it just didn't exist at the time), nor the bone lords secrets, etc... Definitely better now, but lacking when I first played.
Act 3:
Okay, now for me to shit on the game. Act 3 was atrocious and horrible. When replaying the game, I had to abuse the Orobor-bot in order to speed run act 3 because I was that sick of it. The only good part of act 3 is the bosses, and the ending fair well. Literally no other aspect managed to intrigue me, even with the latest update. I didn't care for the Mycologist, or the Bone Lord, nor the fun/unique cards, nor the energy style cost system, nor the items, nor the room design, etc... This just wasn't it chief... If you know what is good for you, use Act 2 to build the Oroborus up, then use 4:00 on the clock puzzle to get it back in Act 3.
Kaycee's Mod:
A return to form for me, and a well-deserved one. I did a video on my YouTube channel called "Why I continue to love a game I cannot beat" which was all about the joys I was having with Kaycee's Mod. Yes, there is brutal and cruel RNG, but that is what you get in an alpha state. I have managed to beat it, and I still come back to experience more and more, because it is well worth it. I look forward to the changes here impacting the main game. One wish I had was that, since the player can handy-cap themselves for challenge points, perhaps a reverse system? Handy-cap Leshy, but at the cost of losing challenge points yourself. Might do well to balance the game.
A tad grindy at times but it does help you learn some of the mechanics and nuances of the game. Definitely a unique and fun experience.

THE DEMO IS BARELY ACCURATE

This game is not a roguelike/roguelite. It is a story game.

If you want a story this is a good game. if you want a mechanically fun card game, look somewhere else

The first act of this game is good fun, interesting mechanics, mysterious, and a fun to play card game with some roguelike elements. And then all that gets launched into the Bootes void. and is replaced by some very boring dragged out and predictable story. Act three has some kinda cool boss mechanics, but thats not enough too save the game from its mechanical blunders.

If you are familiar with Daniel Mullins games and enjoy them, then you will likely enjoy this game as well. However calling this game a roguelike, strategy, or puzzle game is just a lie. Only 1 third of the game can barely be considered a roguelike. while there is room for strategy, it doesnt matter, you can blindly choose whatever you feel like and will have no issues. As for the puzzle, maybe you could call some of them puzzles, but for the most part all the answers are handed too you on a platter. Maybe if you want to call the meta elements of the game a puzzle i can roll with that but once all that is solved its over, the game wont provide you with a puzzle experience.

Under the "Daniel Mullins" there is a decent base for what could be a really cool game. Unfortunately is buried under "Stuff".

A lot of games try to do this "not-what-it-seems" type of genre where it breaches out of the bondaries of what you think you are playing into something completely different.

No one of those games holds a candle to Inscryption.

At its core, you have to know that it's a turn based card game, and that is going to be present through the whole game. So if you like that type of table top, old Yugioh-esque games, then you will love every second of it.

I personally don't really like that genre, but I played it nevertheless because every review says it's more than that. 

And it is. It is much more that a card game, and the ways that the developers have implemented a twist of so many genres and art styles is testament to that. 

If you like games that have a plot deeper than what you play, that will get you to go watch a YouTube video explaining all the things that you may have missed, all the stuff outside of the game that was meant to be found (as in an ARG game) and you like to be surprised, then this game is for you.

I abide by what all the other reviews say.

Go in blind, don't google anything, don't watch playthroughs, don't read any review that goes in depth about the story. 

Let Inscryption surprise you, and you will come out of the other end feeling like it was really, never about a card game.

How have I been sleeping on this masterpiece? I should have trusted the Daniel Mullins seal of approval sooner - if anybody else is holding out because of the card game aspect, there's a *lot* of permanent upgrades as you progress and you can certainly brute force your runs over time, so don't let that hold you back. There is definitely deep strategy involved, but I've found it to be more fun than frustrating because of well the whole experience is pieced together (that said, there will be nearly indecipherable puzzles that you'll have to pick a random item to get hints on). Beyond the card game aspect, Inscryption really feels & plays much more like a "choose-your-own-RPG" game with very intrinsic world that continually develops the plot. This is definitely a unique experience worth trying.

Edit:
Everything I initially wrote was regarding Act 1. Unfortunately, the game really begins to test your patience in the additional acts by doubling down on all the frustrating card game parts. You'll be forced to re-learn to play (several times), RNG will decide most fights, and the puzzles will become more cryptic with less rewards. This could just be the difficulty curve, but it felt like it became increasingly more of a chore compared to the very strong beginning this game had where most decisions were rewarded with interesting plot developments like a choose-your-own-RPG adventure. It's a fantastic experience if you stop after Act 1, but I would be very hesitant to recommend any of it past that.

hey guys its me Leshy from the hit game inscryption

Inscryption, the definitive successor to The Hex and Pony Island by Daniel Mullins, is a card game with a psycho figure obscured in shadow inside of a cabin in the woods. That is it. The card game as a unique mechanic of sacrificing weaker cards to be able to play stronger cards like a simplified version of Yu-Gi-Ho, but I've never played it so I could be completely mistaken. I particularly like this mechanic since it prevents the player from just choosing all of the best cards and calling it a day and gives the game a lot more replay ability since this is a card game and only a card game.

     Leshy's cold demeanor is a perfect mood setter that puts the player in a state of mind that there could be actual danger and consequences for when you lose, though that is of course a false sense that is intended by the game through clever world building. The game can not hurt you. The character of Leshy makes perfect chemistry with the quippy and funny characteristics of...well there is no one else in the cabin, so I don't really know where I was going with this.

     The game's mechanics get very compellingly expanded upon later on in Inscryption in ways that I would have never expected when they don't because the game doesn't expand on the mechanics since there is no later part of the game where there is anything. Anyone who says otherwise is wrong. They are all wrong. How many times do I have to say this. There is only this; let me have this. When there was the massive revelation the game was going to continue and that nothing would change [spoiler]and that Kaycee THERE IS NO KAYCEE[/spoiler] was what I wanted all along. The ARG portions really go above and [spoiler]no no no no no no no. I didn't want to know. I didn't want to know. I didn't want to know. I didn't want to know. I didn't want to know. I didn't want to know.[/spoiler] The data. [spoiler]That code in evil's pocket. Poison.[/spoiler]

Inscryption is separated into three different acts, some of which I like more than others. However as a whole the game is amazing. Act 1 is my favourite as the card game itself is the most fun to me and I also believe act 1 has the best atmosphere and progression system. I do not like act 2 very much, to me it is just a direct downgrade to act 1 in almost every way. Act 3 is somewhere in the middle between act 1 and act 2 in terms of enjoyment for me personally. However I am not reviewing three separate games and although I may like some acts better than others in the grand story each arc is essential and each arc compliments the other if looked at in retrospect after completing the game. The story is very unexpected and best gone into blind so will not elaborate on it further beyond the fact that I enjoyed it overall. Best of all the first act is available to play as an endless mode with modifiers after completing the story giving Inscryption good replay-ability. Overall Inscryption is a completely unique game that is worth playing and the endless mode is good mindless fun even now.

This game is fantastically executed, with much more content than what I expected initially. The lore is very good and the way the game connect things is awesome, with different modes to play the game in Acts 1, 2 and 3, and then Kaycee's mod to provide more challenge (**cough** skull storm **cough**) and new content.

Furthemore, the card play itself is awesome, with many ways to combine cards, and different ways to play through the acts. This is the second game in which I got all achievements in steam, because for most games when I finish them, even when I liked them, they usually don't make me feel like palying again to do more stuff. This wasn't the case with Inscryption. I played the entire story twice and did all the achievements, and did all that because I really wanted to, not just to get the achievements, they just provided new objectives when playing it, and the funny thing is that while doing the achievements, I found some secrets and different ways of play that I had not found in the first run.

Overall, this game is magnific. The only cons I see is the RNG and that there's no way to customize a game the way you want. This could provide more end-game possibilities (choosing the cards you want, totems, abilities, etc..., although you can more or less have more freedom in act 3 if you have a lot of money, that you can get with a boosted ouroboros in act 1 or 2, that remains boosted in act 3).

The RNG sometimes make it that you end up with the worst cards (and you can only discard a number of cards in some places, so it's impossible sometimes to get bad cards), and when playing again you get the same cards (even when you go out and enter the game again). You can change the random seed in the game file to generate new cards, but this is something that I would prefer to have in-game (it's funny that I disn't need any of this when doing skull storm, but sometimes RNG really screw you, and unless you are fine with starting all over again, changing the random seed is the preferable solution IMO). 

There are some ways to make you have a specific card as long as it requires only 1 sacrifice, and it is the only one in the deck with 1 sacrifice (because you always get one 1-sacrifice card at the start of a game), but this can be difficult to achieve sometimes because you can't discard cards except in specific cases, and you also get cards as you progress, and sometimes you can't avoid getting a 1-sacrifice card.

I give this game 9/10. The story can blow up your mind, and the card game itself is very well done.

Hands down the best experience I've ever had in single player gaming - and that's a high bar.

Preferably, go in blind... 

or don't... it doesn't matter... you'll still be surprised at every turn because Daniel Mullins is a genius.

Just when you think you've run out of content, the game surprises you with more.. and even after the credits roll, there's more digging yet to do. Every time you think a certain element of the game is shallow, it slaps you in the face with hidden depth that you didn't know could be hiding in such a humble package.

If the gameplay looks AT ALL appealing to you, you will love this game and then some - I assure you.

At the time of writing this, I have 34 hours in the game and I'm still finding stuff I didn't know was there. Anyone who questions the replayability of this game is nuts - there's just so much meat here.

Magnificent little gem that should be played by anybody who loves videogames.

It's shocking just how many plates this small scale indie project manages to spin in the air: card battler, deck builder, escape the room puzzler, meta narrative and a heck of a mystery to hook you with, all the while staying playfully horrific & never losing its pace.
Hard to praise any specific element of the game (not even the exquisite artistic choices that are also tied to the plot) without spoiling it, so just trust on this one.
If you have a history with videogames - you'll enjoy this one.

Ok. I have to admit, under duress, that this game is pretty damn good.

I don't love it as much as some... I'm certainly not a fan of the way it deliberately obscures some of the rules and mechanics in a few places.. but at it's core there's a pretty neat card game which is fun to play, cloaked in a spooky and effective aesthetic. I'd prefer the rules to be smaller and tighter, rather than sprawling and varied, but that's just me.

Also I'm not particularly fond of the growing power level you experience in the base game, but Kaycee's Mod (Inscryption's answer to Slay the Spire's "Ascension" mode) addresses that issue.

I don't think there's any danger of this knocking Slay the Spire off the top of my favorite games list, but I can see why it does just that for a lot of people. Give it a go if you like that kind of game!

Brilliant game; another great project published through Devolver. This game appears as a deck-builder and becomes so much more. Like many Devolver projects, many of the best things to say about the game also double as spoilers, so I will keep it light.

   Like many other Devolver titles, by buying this game you are buying a few games tied together by a very well-made through line. The mechanics of each sub-game are very well made and teach you important mechanics of each other game. If you like deckbuilders, try this one out. It's a fun card game to solve with multiple viable options. If you like collectible card games, try this one out. There's a ton of great card synergies for your deck. If you like Rogue-likes, you'll like this game. If you like Metroidvanias, you'll like this game. If you like ARGs, this game has a wonderful, intriguing story with many layers to peel open. And somehow, though the main game is best experienced as a first-time game, the developers still managed to put in an alternate gamemode which massively increases replayability.
   Now, if you're wondering how I could possibly liken all of those things to one game, I know for a fact you'll love Inscryption.

[b] The Good (pros) [/b]

- Great card based game, card upgrades are good, not too many and not too few cards to use.

- Amazing visuals and audio, I like that the audio and visuals match perfectly with each Act of the game.

- Feels like a rogue-like in that you'll lose a lot, but there's a feeling of accomplishment when you get further than you did last time.


[b] The Bad (minor cons, just me nitpicking) [b]

- A secret boss is missable, and you require items from previous acts tobe able to access it.

- Some achievements require you to do specific things that're missable on your first playthrough, for instance [spoiler] in act 3 you hafta collect 5 rabbit pelts and give them to the Trader to collect 5 specific tarot cards from him. Of course I didn't know that, so instead of looking for the 4 locations where you can find trap to get a pelt from the rabbit jumping near it or a grinding for money to buy the rabbit pelts from the shop to get the required pelts, I rushed through the act and just spent all of my money on cards and card upgrades. The 5 specific tarot cards are The Tower, The Devil, The Fool, The Empress and Death, of course you could end up buying the wrong tarot cards and messing up the chance to get the achievement! [/spoiler]

[b] The Ugly (major flaws that ruin the game) [/b]

- Having Luke Carder talk while you're playing (you're supposed to be playing as him and seeing through his eyes) really ruins the immersion, and frankly the whole found footage parts of the game and Luke himself should've been removed from the game, it doesn't add anything to the game in my opinion!

TL;DR: Amazing game, just a colossal false advertisement. Almost a thumbs up.

---- [100% Spoiler Free] ----

This is not a rogue-like deck building game. This is a creepy pasta-esque story focused game with card game elements as a narrative tool. It is generally made with care and skill, but while the first part of the story mode is outstanding, I regret playing through the rest to unlock the challenge mode.

The story mode starts of relatively easy, but keeps getting easier as you progress and therefore starts to feel boring and grindy at times. Except for the fights you're supposed to lose, I beat every single encounter on my first try, wasn't even close. When I bought the game, I thought it would be difficult due to the horror aesthetic (and people saying it's hard), so it felt disappointing when I found out you're basically the pharaoh from Yugioh, stacking your deck with literal god cards (yes, that strong). I understand that this decision was made, so bad players wouldn't be locked out of the rest of the content, I understand that playing OP cards is fun, but couldn't they have just given us a challenge mode from the start? Why am I, a card game/rogue-like enthusiast, being under-delivered by a game that advertises itself towards me as its target audience?

Part two and three of the game are purposefully not seen in advertisement material to surprise you. I have mixed feelings about those surprises and if I had known them beforehand, I would have greatly adjusted my expectation.

Overall, the game is still entertaining most of the time, but you can just quit the game after part one and get away with a less bland taste.

Act 1 was fantastic. The gameplay and aesthetic are captivating and immersive. Then it throws you into Act 2, a complete tonal shift in aesthetic. The game keeps its deck-building card game, adds a couple more resource mechanics, and adds a card-collecting element. However, Act 2 changes the visual (and interface) experience to a generic fantasy RPG setting. This made me lose all interest in progressing through the game. A terrible mistake for the sake of  a "meta game" narrative. Extremely disappointing.
This game is not what you think it is. Just play it, you won't regret it.

[8/10] I got this game on sale and started playing non-stop after because it's so addicting when you get new cards and keep buffing your card deck. I've finished the main game and I beat level 1 of Kaycee's mod, it was really fun but, the only downside is it makes me infuriated that the cards that I worked hard on are all erased every time you beat a challenge level. I know the point of the mod is "challenges" but, for me it was more like the deck-building aspect of the game that I was addicted to and why I kept playing. So this will be the last time I will be playing the game until there is a mode that lets you keep your cards that you worked hard on buffing or gives you 3 card options to keep from your deck. :(
Thanks a lot Kaycee for getting my blue ribbon revoked T-T

I played it a bit. All was fine and interesting until the opponent tried to kill me like a frustrated game master tries to kill his player's characters by summoning without warning a (supposedly) unbeatable board. It ruined everything for me. Why would you struggle and fight if the opponent can just decide to summon an army and kill you whenever he wants.

I was feeling my opponent was being monstruous, but fair. He isn't. It's possible to win, of course. But it just ruined the atmosphere for me. I don't see why he wouldn't just do that every single time since he apparently doesn't care much about being fair.

If the atmosphere is gone, all that is left is the card game. It's a good one. But I was attracted to the atmosphere, not the gameplay mechanics. Now I lost interest.

Two years later I decided to give it another go. Beat Leshy, turns out I have some random puzzles to solve now ? A knife is supposed to be used to pluck an eye or whatever but just doesn't appear, also, the game is way too repetitive, I was already bored at the end of a single run. It's way too annoying to have to do it again just because I missed a puzzle. 

They definitely put a lot of effort in the packaging of the game but in the end it's just boring to play. Always the same thing. Also, the "breaking the fourth wall" stuff was already done to the bone, it's just predictable and not interesting. Uninstalled again.

Overall the experience is simply frustrating.

Amazing game, interesting gameplay and twists, with challenges that are tough but not too hard to solve.

The game is enjoyable, and you should buy the game on discount if you enjoy the roguelite deckbuilder genre, but be aware that the game is a relatively short and shallow experience, and the fun part is roughly about a third of the entire game (which to be fair, is extended by the replayability of Kaycee's mod). 

Act 1 is the most enjoyable part of the game, though as previously mentioned, I think it is rather short and shallow compared to other games in the genre. The escape-room element of the game is a novel addition to the genre, and I enjoyed how the interactive elements impacted the card game. Kaycee's mod is a good addition to extend the experience of act 1 gameplay, although it does remove most of the interesting escape-room elements in the name of balance and replayability. 

Act 2 and 3, I merely tolerated and powered through to reach the ending, though it is nice to see various tweaks to the deckbuilder genre, even if they make the game less enjoyable. Yes, in the canon and lore of the game they are supposed to be "less refined versions", but outside of that you as a consumer of a game you purchased is still experiencing rather dull portions of the game which encompasses TWO out of the three acts so far.

Act 4 plays some of the remaining iterations introduced in act 2, but gameplay is so sparse that I don't think it's fair to judge how well thought out the mechanics are (I barely touched them in act 2 too), and without the interesting life or death stakes of act 1; Act 4 really mostly just cutscenes, with some interactive element that doesn't mean much, and then the game ends.
Deeper and better game than it looks! One of the best card games. Even if you don't like board games, you should still give it a try.
squirrell

Every once in a while, someone comes up with a brilliant idea. They go on to create the Sixtine Chapel or the Mona Lisa. Daniel Mullins went and made Inscryption.

Just extraordinary. It doesn't end where you think it ends, hell, it doesn't even start where you think it starts.

Without spoiling too much, the overarching narrative to Inscryption feels like it's missing something to really push it over the top and make it a magical meta-narrative, though it still means it has many surprises to show you. The escape room flavouring feels a bit undercooked, but the actual card game underneath is incredibly solid. It's missing some of the flexibility needed to make it a truly fair roguelike card game experience, but the breadth of modifiers and things to keep track of make progress feel gratifying. The unlockable Kaycee's Mod is almost as addictive as Slay The Spire as a result.

Inscryption is a game that lingers in my mind even after completing it. Wonderful Job!

Someone saw "Slay The Spire" and thought "Damn! This game is great! what if this was bad instead?"

The biggest issue in the game is that you're intentionally made to starve cards, since you can either choose to pull a creature or squirrel card at the start of your turn with the "Squirrel" cards being like a basic resource card. Meaning that you're at a constant net loss of hand size at each turn, leading to you quickly running out of playable cards. There's another resource of "bones", but since that requires other creatures to die first, it means that is also a constant resource loss. There's no equillibrium of resources. But your opponent does not have to abide by these rules at all, he does not have to sacrifice or use bones. He can just play cards to his hearts content with no restrictions. So you're at a constant power loss and he's at a constant power gain. The only thing you have up against him is that you can see his planned moves, but it doesnt help much when he starts his turn by playing 3 cards and you can only realistically play one or two. 

The game also looks bad, I'm packing a 3070 in my PC yet the game looks  like it cant decide if it came out today or 1998. 

Awful game that looks bad. Stay away.

What a ride. I've never played a game quite like this, it starts as one thing and then slowly you realize that it's much more. It's hard to get into any detail without spoiling the game. Most rogue-likes lack narrative and characters, this one definitely doesn't. To paraphrase the user review that convinced me to buy it, don't read about or watch any videos on it, just buy it and play it.

The game is unreal and it can only be played once, so go buy it and jump right in, it's a masterpiece :)

10/10 PLEASE TRY THE GAME. 

After reading some of the reviews, I think the best advice i took and want to give back out is that you should go into the game BLIND and refrain from looking up walkthroughs or anything that would spoil yourself of the experience. If you're a scaredy-cat like me, and is scared that this game is going to scare the **** out of you, it wont. It's more atmospherically "scary" than scary at all, no jumpscares, and I was actually having a lot of fun.

The game was very immersive, unlike many different roguelite card builders I've tried before. The story was actually very interesting and took me by surprise at every turn. A little bit of escape the room type of puzzles, and thrills/suspense. It keeps you wondering what's going to happen next. Just went you think the game is over, it's not. 

10/10 , I only wish I can play this game all over again for the first time. 

Don't read this next part if you haven't finished the game: [spoiler] I think one of my most favorite part is Act 3, when they accessed my files and used my own friends against me. I just really enjoyed that they always had a few elements of surprise at almost every turn, you almost never know what's going to happen next. I liked that it's unpredictable. At the finale end, I actually felt sad and bittersweet shaking their hands and saying good bye, I kind of wished the game wasn't truly over already. Now I feel empty and hope to find another roguelite card builder such as this again. [/spoiler] Thank you for the amazing experience. :')

This game fundamentally plays with the trope that most devs will refer to a mechanic during narrative that they will never actually implement in game. Inscryption somehow maintains the low expectations we've tacitly developed with just a lot of bad content especially in the casual and mobile space, but it does so to string us along just long enough to stun us when they shatter those expectations. It was a thrill, thanks devs!

Inscryption is a wholly unique experience, and I rarely say that about most games I've played, but Daniel Mullins has created something truly spectacular here. Like most, I went in expecting to play another seemingly ordinary card game. But, just like most people, I was quickly proven wrong. Inscryption is an eccentric beast of a game, one that prides itself on its rich and dense horror atmosphere and sound design, nonlinear meta storytelling as well as its addicting roguelite gameplay. In short, it's a card game unlike any other. An experience that utterly has no parallel. Trust me, my words alone cannot do it justice. Although somewhat premature of me to declare this so soon after finishing, it wouldn't surprise me if Inscryption ends up being fondly remembered and lauded by future generations of gamers, in the same vein as titles as Bioshock, as the game that helped pushed its genre forward in a brighter and more innovative direction. And frankly, I don't think there's a greater compliment a game can receive than that. For your consideration: Inscryption.

Excellent game, if you like deck building games, RPGs, and total mindbending experiences, this is the game for you. The mechanics of your cards change with a roguelike customization process, and you can improve cards you already have or get new ones, and it's different on each run. The game also extends far beyond what you think it will be, and get significantly more bizarre as it goes. Don't quit if you think you're done.

[h1] NON-SPOILER [/h1]
The story, gameplay and even end-game content was quite enjoyable. Each run felt unique and enjoyable. This game goes above and beyond to immerse you in its world and story, there was rarely a moment where I felt like it was over explaining or babying the player with its story/gameplay.

There were moments of confusion, but I'd chalk that up as a skill issue than anything else. I'd happily recommend all of my friend's to try this game out.

[h1] SPOILER WARNING [/h1]
[spoiler] The twists of the story as well as in-game recordings provide a clear idea of whats going on while still sprouting questions for the player. It's a form of story telling I rarely see and had me on the edge of my seat. I was never bored during cut scenes or dialogue. One gripe I do have is moreso with gameplay than story. At times, you could come up incredibly unlucky or receive a totem battle thats nigh impossible to win. If you aim for specific synergies, its possible to really beat any and all modes. Such as immortal bee or immortal cat. If you try to be creative in Casey's Mod, there's a high likelihood of being punished for it simply due to luck. Lastly, I do wish you could make "Custom Cards" in Casey's Mod like you can in the story. [/spoiler]

Inscryption is a phenomenal game that relies too heavily on twist-based Creepypasta tropes. The first act is fantastic, and the gameplay is phenomenal, but underdeveloped. Then, once you actually beat the game, it switches into a completely different game, and is now an oldschool pokemon style RPG with four dungeons. It kept core gameplay mechanics, but added new casting types which were RNG dependent and unreliable. The dungeons were alright, but you had to pick a single starter deck out of the four and commit to it, while obtaining cards of different casting types, each one exclusive to the dungeon. This made obtaining packs a chore, as I already had a powerful deck crafted that could beat the bosses after a couple of attempts -besides the wizard one, I had to make a new deck for him.- The dungeons had for the most part interesting but easy puzzles that I didn't mind too much. Once beating this, however, I'm now playing a version of Inscryption that is basically act 1 of Inscryption but without all the fun stuff. Instead of it being a grisly roguelike, with and eerie atmosphere filled with intrigue, it is a boring pathway walker. Where dying was unique and exciting in Act 1, deaths hardly matter but they make you walk all the way back to where you died to pick up your gold, new mechanics are barely explained, and mistakes you make affect your cards permanently. The casting system is changed from a unique sacrifice system to a hearthstone-esque energy system, and the cards are significantly weaker. I don't even want to finish it because Act Three is a slog. 
My advice:
Play this game, but don't beat it.

Avoid spoilers and enjoy this absolute gem of a game

After playing the game for almost 40 hours and beating it a few times from start to finish, Inscryption has been one of the games that I periodically come back to when I have nothing else to play which is why I'd have to say that it sits comfortably in my top 5 favourite games of all time. The game consists of multiple parts (I wont spoil what happens) however, the changes between sections can feel a little jarring at first but every new section builds upon the beauty of the game. Each section brings a new twist on the established game play mechanics that keeps game play fresh and exciting. In my opinion I think that the first section of the game is the best as it has the best story telling aspects. Which is why after beating the game I like to run loops of the first section because it is that fun. If you haven't played this game yet do yourself a favour and buy it even if you haven't had much experience with deck builders.

Solid 9.4/10

[b][u]The trailer is misleading.[/u][/b] The game shown in pretty much the entire trailer is only half of the game. STRONGLY disagree with other reviews which says "go in blind, it's best that way"

For about 6 hours I had an absolute blast playing the first part, getting really into the atmosphere, music, art style, the roguelike parts, the escape room style setting, and so on, and if the game simply ended after that it would've been an instant recommend. Genuinely so much fun

Then they make a really strange decision to COMPLETELY change the game, keeping the card battler mechanics but changing all the other parts mentioned above that I was really enjoying. The part you see at about 0:32 of the trailer, for about half a second (the card battler board but as pixel art - literally blink and you miss it) is what the entire second act of the game consists of. To a player like me who isn't familiar with other card battlers, the game suddenly just falls off a cliff and stops being fun.

Even worse though, after talking to people who've played through the whole thing, the game's (shorter) third part has a feature which takes random file names from your computer and uses them as card names. I stream on Twitch as a hobby - there are files on my computer which, if they'd been used as names, would have immediately doxxed me and revealed extremely sensitive personal information about me. There's no option to turn this off. This is such a monumentally awful decision that I don't think I'm ever going to buy a game from this developer again

The meta, fourth-wall-breaking narrative is really not all that interesting. In the space of 20 minutes I went from "this could be one of my favourite games ever" to "this is one of the biggest letdowns I've ever experienced in a video game". There's an endless mode mod that I'd love to play but I'm not willing to slog through the second act to get there. Please don't listen to steam reviews telling you to go in blind.

If I could, I would give Inscryption a very neutral, 5/10 rating. 
Since Steam requires a yes/no recommendation, I'm leaning more towards not recommending.
I followed the advice of the 90k+ positive reviews and played the game without doing any prior research.
I only saw that it is a very popular horror, card game from the tags and decided to buy it for Halloween, hoping for a scare.

So. How does Inscryption fair against those genres?

Card game:
It is first and foremost a deck-building, card game. A very easy one that can sometimes feel rigged based on RNG, which is never a good feeling. Sure, there are rogue-like elements to it. But the only times during runs that I really felt challenged was only on the first map of Act 1 because I hadn't had a chance to build my deck yet.
They introduce more and more game mechanics and card effects at a good pace as you progress through the game.
However, once you reach a new Act in the story, they throw away almost all previous mechanics instead of building on them.
It felt like such a wasted opportunity for the gameplay.

Horror:
There were exactly THREE moments in my entire ELEVEN HOUR play-through that were scary. THREE! IN ELEVEN HOURS!! Two of them were from [spoiler]self-mutilation[/spoiler] and one was [spoiler]a cheap jump scare[/spoiler] . And all THREE of them happened during Act 1, which I finished in just over 2 hours (little too late for a refund).
Act 2 completely destroyed the creepy atmosphere built in Act 1, and had zero scares.
Act 3 felt similar to Act 1 as it tried to repair the creepy atmosphere, except it was much weaker in scale and without a single scare. 
THREE SCARES! IN ELEVEN HOURS!!
This is abysmally bad for a "Horror" game.
If anything, playing Inscryption felt more like reading creepy-pasta on a bright, sunny day in the middle of a park that turned into a child-like fan-fic.



Now, I've mentioned Acts a lot in the review so I'll explain it a little. Without spoiling anything, there are 3 story Acts in Inscryption. Act 1 is what you see in all of the promotional material. It's a rogue-like, deck building game happening in an escape room scenario. It's a very interesting premise. BUT IT'S ONLY TWO HOURS LONG! Maybe even shorter if you're experienced in deck building games and puzzles! The majority of the game is NOT shown, and for good reason. Acts 2 and 3 are terrible. And a complete waste of time for the story as there is zero payoff/impact in the finale.
It just abruptly ends.

So, with all of these negatives, why would I still give it a neutral rating?
Act 1. Act 1 carried the game in terms of fun from the deck-building, rogue-like gameplay. It carried the game in the creepy atmosphere and (very limited) horror. It carried the game in story, because there was almost none of it and everything was mysterious. It carried the game with the unique premise of an escape room.
So the way I look at it, I spent $10 for admission to a creepy, 2-hour escape room with an easy card game.
Not a bad deal.

If all of the game development time spent on Acts 2 and 3 were instead invested it into expanding Act 1, I think this game could have been at least an 8/10. Maybe even a 10/10.

And I have one bit of advice for horror storytelling.
Sometimes, less is more.
The mystery is more interesting than the explanation.

Inscryption by far is one of my all time favorite games to have come out in recent years. A seemingly benign deck-building escape room with differing mechanics for each act of the game, while keeping the core mechanics unchanged. The story is unsettling to some degree, but it draws you in, using very clever and intuitive narrative devices. Did I mention this game has secrets to find; as well as an in-game ARG that expands on the already existing lore within the game. This game is definitely worth every second spent playing it, I would highly recommend it to anyone.

Hands down one of the best games I've played in my life. It's a rogue-lite turn-based deck-building card battler with a lot more mystery, depth, and intrigue than most games I've played. That said, it's also a SHORT game... 10-20 hours for the main game playthrough, and a challenge mode afterward that's not going to be for everyone.

Because it's got mystery/puzzle elements, if you plan to try it out I strongly advise just getting the game and going straight into it without doing any reading, research, or self-spoiling. The game will seed subtle hints both during and between runs, so don't go looking for guides until you're desperate and spinning wheels for at least a few (3 or so) runs in a row, and even then just get the next clue and go before you see anything else.

Spoilers below:

I am not exactly sure what happened but this game grabbed me under the rug and pulled me into an all day gaming session, with me completing the entire thing within 14 hours.

Right out of the gate, the premise is very intriguing. Left abandoned in a shack, a curious looking figure invites you to a card game called Inscryption and challenges you to complete his entire gaunlet of 3 stages, with lining up cards to deal damage and eventually return victorious. He lets you also explore the inner workings of the shack for some light puzzle solving. The cool thing about this is that both the shack and the card game work in tandum with each other, causing things to get affected in the card game and vice versa. It made the first few hours of the game especially interesting, because even if you're not too huge into card games, you still have an escape room puzzle solving element to look forward to. 
It also certainly helped the card game itself was a joy to interact with, and the rougelite elements kept it from being boring, making you actually think of deck builds. In general, the setup was well done and I loved the somewhat creepy atmosphere alongside it.

Tthe card game itself and the rules for it are really fun and are definetly the main focus. Act 1 starts out somewhat simple and devolves into a fun, slightly complex ruleset fitting for different playstyles. The Kaycee Mod acting as a rougelike of Act 1 you get to play after beating the game is a welcoming mode that I am sure I will check out more later. 


However, this is a Daniel Mullins game. There will be a twist in this game, and this came in the form of throwing the entire premise out the window to reveal there are actually 2 more different acts with slight variations of the card ruleset waiting ahead. Act 2 introduced itself as an 8-bit top down adventure game, with more card types being introduced. 

While I personally do not mind this change, the entire of Act 2 should have been kept in the same style as Act 1. I just feel it's a massive wasted opportunity to recontextulaise the creepy atmosphere of the shack with the other scrybes, as I would have much more preferred to travel in first person with those weird 4 directional movement options, in addition to the light puzzle elements in both Act 1 and 3. It would've made for a more fun and consistent package, especially since Act 3 returns to that same style. I don't know, it just feels like a twist for the sake of being one, and not because it does anything terribly interesting with it.

Speaking of, if you're expecting 4th wall breaks like in Pony Island, you won't get them as extensive as here, just remaining as a fun gimmick and nothing else. The game is played from a PoV essentially recording their lets play of Inscryption, residing as an actual phsyical copy in a floppy disk reader. You will not see him much either. The area of mystery outside the video game Inscryption is solidly made, though I wish you could interact with it more yourself, instead of having just prerecorded videos pop up every now and then. (They are still good and do lead you towards an ARG if you want to get into that more, I meant more inside the actual game itself, though I understand if that was not the focus.)

Regardless of the few negative points listed here, I still had a lot of fun playing this strange little card game for hours on end. Highly recommend!

I have been waiting to play this game for so long and jumped on it as soon as it went on sale. I am a huge fan of Daniel Mullins Games. Enjoyed Pony Island with my friends and LOVED the mystery story behind The Hex. Now we enter my new favorite genre, roguelite card battler with a horror twist? Sign me up!

Like most of DM's Games, it is better for you to go in as blind as possible so you can get the full effect and mystery of it all. So I will only go over as little as possible. You awaken in a cabin and play a card game with some weird man. As he goes through the tutorial, you realize there are other places (and puzzles) to solve around the cabin, but you'll have to best him in the game to find clues as to what's going on. Some of the cards talk, there are some flashing lights behind a locked door, and the whole vibe is eerie. Can you figure it out?

Inscryption requires you to sacrifice weaker cards to summon stronger ones or to collect coins from fallen creatures. It may take some getting used to, but it's fairly easy to learn. Cards can also have special abilities called sigils that let them do cool things. It can be as simple as flight so they can attack over defending cards or having it so they switch lanes after attacking. It's incredibly fun and quite addictive once you get into the swing of things.

As stated earlier, there are also puzzles to solve around the cabin. Think of it like an escape room. You have to find clues to solve them and you will gain new cards and discover more lore as to what is REALLY going on in this game. I will admit that I had to look up a solution every so often, but it was also fun to figure out most of them on my own. I implore you to try to solve them on your own first before looking up solutions.

The horror aspect of the game is a great blend. I'm not a fan of horror games personally, but since this was more atmospheric horror and not jump-scare horror, it really made it more enjoyable. I loved the music and overall feel of the game and can even recommend it to players who may feel uneasy with horror games.

I personally had no gripes with the game. Most times when I lost runs was either because of bad card RNG or me not picking good cards. I loved unraveling the mystery the more I played and I do intend to beat it again to get more clues.

Final verdict? I cannot recommend this game enough. If you like roguelite card games with a dash of horror and puzzles, this is the perfect game for you. Like I said, I kept this as brief and concise as I could to prevent spoilers, so do yourself a favor. If you even just considering getting this, just do it, you won't regret it...Thanks for reading!

Allow me to frontload some info quickly: I've played Magic: the Gathering at a locally competitive level for a couple of years. Not going to lie, I was very confident that my prior experience in the TCG realm would make this a pushover. I was [b] so [/b] wrong. I can smile after beating the game, I wasn't ready when I started. If you're on the fence about this game, here's the slim:

[h3] Story [/h3]
It's perfect for Halloween season. It's dark, deep, and meta. I loved it because it felt [i] real [/i]. Not to mention, it's told very well.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
It's a card game, there's a lot learn. Nothing is too difficult but if you don't like reading, you're going to lose [b] a lot [/b]. Mechanics are simple and straightforward. Just know, this game doesn't pull punches. If you mess up one turn, at least you get to enjoy a photo opportunity!

[h3] Graphics [/h3]
If you're playing a card game for great graphics you're doing it right. Betcha didn't expect to read that sentence! Don't get me wrong, it's a bit jarring to go from 3D to 2D but it's art direction is done so well that the transition is easy. 

[h3] Music [/h3]
I'm sure there is a formal name for the style but, it's moody, enjoyable, and pairs with the visual atmosphere well. I stopped gaming a few times to enjoy the ambiance. It's [b] that [/b] good.

[h3] TL;DR [/h3]
It's very good.

Inscryption, a realm where cards of power and mystique art the protagonists, entwines the soul within a narrative, captivating and shrouded in enigma. Thee, as the player, art drawn into a duel of wits, challenging the intellect and fortitude. Thee must wield cunning strategies and shrewdness to outwit the challenges afore thee.

Thee art enveloped within a gripping narrative, delving deep into the realm of the arcane and the supernatural, thy path obscured by riddles and mysteries. The journey unfolds akin to an ancient scroll, unfurling its secrets bit by bit, enticing the player ever deeper into its enigmatic tapestry.

The mechanics of card play within Inscryption art deftly crafted, blending elements of strategy, risk, and chance. Each duel requires thoughtful consideration and astute planning, with a touch of unpredictability that keeps the heart racing.

Furthermore, the aesthetic presentation of this digital fable is nothing short of masterful, with artistry that conjures an atmosphere both foreboding and alluring. The melding of sound and visual elements, an enchanting symphony that draws thee further into the mystical realm.

Thee art entreated to venture into Inscryption with an open heart and a discerning mind, for its challenges art many and its rewards great. 'Tis a realm of riddles and strategy, an odyssey that shall surely enthrall the stout of heart and sharp of wit.

Edit:
The review I wrote below is ignorant, uneducated, and downright wrong. After finishing this game I can confidently say that Inscryption is one of the best experiences I've ever had with a video game. I felt violated playing this, like the game knew who I was and that I was playing it. This game is a straight up masterpiece.

The only reason I'm recommending this game is because of act 1.

The first act is incredible. It's suspenseful, the animation and pacing is next-level, the art style, and the absolute creeps you get from staring into his eyes in a dark room. It's unlike any deck builder I've ever played and the actual card game itself is so simple yet complex (aside from high-cost cards being near worthless since the matches are so short and can be finished in literally a single turn if you have two 3/1 flyers). 

But I only wish the entire game stayed in the first act.

I have to give credit to the devs for making such an original and creative game, but act 2 and 3 simply can't compare to how good 1 is. Not because it's not good, but because you only get to play a few hours of the best part and are forced into pixel art after something that's incredibly immersive. It's not that pixel art is inherently bad (stardew is one of my all-time favs), it's just that the game subverts your expectation, but not in a good way - in my opinion, at least.

It only took me around 3 hours to beat Act 1, and if I knew about how garbage the game turned afterwards I would've let the guy give me a personnel photo shoot again. Act 2 is simply not fun, no interesting mechanics, just reattempting the bosses over and over until you draw what you need to. The aesthetic of the game goes from what is advertised to being somehow worse than what RPG Maker could produce for the PS2. Honestly really disappointed with how it just seems like the game kind of tricks you into thinking it is this super deep Rogue-Like deckbuilder, then once it really starts to get good, pulls the rug from underneath you and says "you already played for so long, why not keep playing even though we stopped caring."


Apparently there is a mod that just lets you stay in Act 1, so any time I play after making this review will be because of that.
