BUY IT NOW WHILE ITS ON SALE! A truly amazing game, I loved every minute of it. Its essentially a cross between 'Slay the Spire' and 'Gent' from the Witcher, with a few mini-puzzles thrown in and a darker atmosphere.  You build a deck and then card-battle with the bad guy, Leshy, and his minions. Death is inevitable but that's OK, you get resurrected and try again, it gets easier each time as you learn how it all works and maximise the power of each card. You also get hints and tips from some talking cards in your deck, and gradually solve the mini puzzles with their help. Eventually you will triumph over Leshy and feel like you've really earned it, I shouted 'YES!' and fist pumped when he finally fell. 

But then after you finish the first part the second part is truly terrible, a simplistic retro game from about 30 years ago, horrible music, graphics and game play. I gave up after ten minutes. Still, there's easily enough in the first part to make it good value for money, just think of it as a stand alone game and ignore the second bit.

Inscryption is a remarkable and innovative game that seamlessly blends deck-building, roguelike, and puzzle elements, offering players an engrossing and enigmatic experience. Its gripping storyline, complete with a dark and foreboding atmosphere, keeps players intrigued and immersed. The deck-building mechanics are expertly designed, encouraging creative card combinations, while the roguelike elements ensure replayability and uniqueness in every playthrough. The challenging puzzles and striking art style add to the game's overall appeal, making Inscryption an exceptional title that pushes the boundaries of its genres, providing a captivating and memorable gaming experience for fans of diverse genres.

[h1]Inscryption is a great game.[/h1] 

The content that you get for the price is a good amount and even after you have 100 percented the game you can still have fun replaying it. It is a mystery game mixed with roguelike elements and some puzzles along the way. The less you know about the game, the more fun you will have unearthing the different secrets and layers the game has locked away. Also the game has a surprisingly large amount of time before you actually reach the credits (took me 62 hours and I had watched a couple playthroughs and used some cheeky exploits in gameplay).

If you have seen some playthroughs or know a little bit about the game then this breakdown will be helpful otherwise these are spoilers that you should avoid looking at.

[h1] Review [/h1]
[spoiler] 
[h2]Act 1 - Best part of the entire game[/h2]
it has the most engaging content and feels fresh each time you play through it because of your new knowledge going into each run. This is perfection.

[h2] Act 2 - 3rd best part in the game[/h2]
I'm a bit split with this part because while it had fun parts in it with a god amount of puzzles it was slow at the beginning. This part really starts to flesh out the lore of the in game characters but the gameplay feels dissatisfying when compared to the first part. However, it was really fun seeing the characters especially [spoiler]goobert and stimulation <3[/spoiler]

[h2] Act 3 - This was more grating than when I put cheese on my pasta (I fucking love Parmigiano-Reggiano) [/h2]
This feels like starvation. It feels like you have little to no resources. This really doesn't change much the entire (what feels like) 15 hours of gameplay. There is really no problem if you die so the fights aren't high stress but if I had to play through that game much longer I may have just stopped playing. Also you wont get your files deleted; I checked and you're fine.

[h2] Act4 Cool and also haha funny [/h2]
This is a very brief part of the game and really just the main ending. Not much to say really except for te fact that I was so close to beating Magnificus (trust me).

[h2] Casey's Mod [/h2]
Casey's Mod has got it going on. It's all I want and I've waited for so long. I know it might be wrong but I'm in love with Casey's Mod.
But seriously Casey's Mod is a coin flip between best and second best part of the game. It won't feel as magical as your first playthrough of act 1, but it will make up for it with the amount of content both in new cards, mechanics, and difficulty modifiers as well as sheer length that it will take you to fully complete it.

[/spoiler]

[h1] Glitches that I've Found [/h1]
Note: I assume that you have played the game so there are spoilers in here.
[spoiler]
Take it or leave em but I think I should at least share them for both the devs and players to see. Really the only one is that you can re-pick a path choice if you click esc or tab and exit to the main menu and then continue back into your game.
There is some balance breaking cheese when it comes to play in Casey's mod.
     First and foremost, when trading your pelts in the very begginning, because it is the first spot on the map, when you reload the game the map reshuffles and so do the cards that you can trade for. This is the same ffor after each boss fight. You can reload the map to get a more ideal layout like an early goobert space. 
     Speaking of goobert, (amazing segway I know) you can reload his painting if you do it right. I havent really abused this too much because i think it takes good timing but it should be able to give you more ideal duplicates.
      When you are picking a normal pick 3 or a pick based on kin or cost, you can see what you would have gotten for each and take which one is ideal through this exploit. You can also do this for the trials with the dude in the cave (idk what its called).
      You can scope out different parts of a fork in the path. If you want to see what you would get in a woodcarver, you can. Also if you wanted to see what items you would have gotten if you chose the pack you can. Again you just go into the menu and click continue game.
      The combination between reloading the map and the fact that the final map before Leshy is the same each time means that you can really easily get an overpowered sigil for your totem. Knowing this can make the final boss the easiest part of the entire game.
      [h3]THE MOST BROKEN PARTS OF THIS GLITCH[/h3]

      If you are about to lose a fight you can instead reload the fight and try again. It is so easy and the timing is very lenient as well. Casey's mod is hard because you lose a lot but if you just use this exploit you wont lose unless your deck sucks.
[/spoiler]

A Masterpiece of Twisted Brilliance

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

Inscryption is a tour de force of game design, a triumph that defies easy categorization. It seamlessly weaves together elements of card-based strategy, psychological horror, and narrative storytelling into a tapestry of pure genius. From the moment I stepped into its eerie, enigmatic world, I knew I was in for something truly special.

The cards, the heart and soul of Inscryption, are a stroke of brilliance. Each one is a testament to the meticulous craftsmanship of the developers, offering a staggering array of strategic possibilities. The depth of the card mechanics is nothing short of astounding, allowing for infinite customization and ensuring that every playthrough feels fresh and exhilarating.

The integration of a captivating narrative within a card game is a feat that few could have imagined, let alone executed with such finesse. The story unfolds in a way that is both unsettling and enthralling, leaving me on the edge of my seat, hungry for every morsel of information. It's a testament to the narrative prowess of the creators that even the most cryptic elements of the plot are irresistibly compelling.

The atmosphere of Inscryption is a masterclass in evoking a sense of dread and wonder. The eerie cabin setting, the haunting soundtrack, and the enigmatic characters all contribute to an immersive experience that is as unsettling as it is captivating. Every creak of the floorboards and flicker of the candlelight is carefully orchestrated to keep players in a state of delicious unease.

The puzzles, both within and outside the card game, are a stroke of genius. They challenge the mind and demand creative thinking, adding a layer of depth that elevates Inscryption from a mere game to a cerebral experience. Each puzzle feels like a revelation, a testament to the designers' commitment to engaging players on multiple levels.

Inscryption's ability to surprise and subvert expectations is a testament to its audacious creativity. The twists and turns, the moments of shock and awe, are executed with a confidence and precision that is rarely seen in the world of gaming. It's a rollercoaster of emotions that left me breathless, craving more.

In conclusion, Inscryption is a magnum opus, a crowning achievement in the realm of indie gaming. It defies convention, challenges expectations, and leaves an indelible mark on the player's psyche. If you have even a passing interest in card games, storytelling, or just experiencing something truly extraordinary, Inscryption is an absolute must-play. It is a masterpiece of twisted brilliance that will haunt my thoughts long after the cards have been dealt.

First off, I would recommend going in blind if you're into a game that will surprise you. If you need the essential review, it's an entertaining enough card game with a lot of good twists in there. The gameplay isn't immaculate but if you're down to put in a little brainpower and some outside-the-box thinking, you'll have a good time.

But I have to give credit where due, this is one of the games that followed me for a while even when I wasn't playing it. After beating it for the first time, it feels as if there's tons of secrets in here, so much so that while the game was very fun, I don't feel like I got a complete story. I'm interested in seeing what the community digs up in terms of hidden content, easter eggs, and whatever else the devs kept well enough hidden from us that they knew we weren't gonna catch it the first time... if it's in there. If it's not... it's a somewhat hollow, if spooky, story.

One of my all-time favorite games Inscryption is one of those games that I think may initially offput people because of the horror card game packaging that it kind of wraps itself in, but that doesn't really tell the story of Inscryption.  This game has a lot of elements that are kind of hidden from the player at the start and relies on the player to slowly find out its secrets through exploration and only very subtle hints.  Every time it seems like you've found everything there is to find there is one more puzzle that is lying in wait you'll need to solve.  There are times where this game is meant to be frustrating and almost "unwinnable" and that's by design.  The game wants you to slow down and explore everything around you rather than just speeding through to the end.  And it's very worth taking your time as it's quite the wild ride

The problem with this game is that spoilers would ruin much of the fun. The name of the game here is subversion of expectations. I went in blind, having seen no gameplay and only checking the reviews, fully expecting it was some sort of horror-themed rogue deckbuilding game, and found out that there was more to it than met the eye.

What impressed me and will stay with me are the visuals. While the gameplay was never complex, just the ability to see yourself, see your cards, play them as if you were in tabletop, see your shady opponent at the other side of the table, and even interact with physical objects as part of the game are quite a change from what this genre is used to, which is mostly minimalistic, static poses with no animations slightly moving to the left and right. Pretty good change of pace.

Inscryption is a strategy deck-building card-battler AND an intriguing exploration of a rich story, wrapped in a nice creepy atmosphere, and with two teaspoons of corruption thrown in. It's hard to find a game that satisfies as many demands as this one. It's a game worthy of its legacy: its brothers are Pony Island and The Hex- and Inscryption is better than both. It takes the unholy, corrupted digital theme of Pony Island and boosts it up to 110%, and not only that, but it's also a pretty decent roguelike, especially with the addition of Kaycee's Mod. Strongly recommended.

Wow... 9/10
NO SPOILERS:

The Good: I had no idea what to expect and I was very pleased. This game takes you down a strange path, with attention to detail the entire way. If you enjoy card games or general strategic play, you will have a fun time progressing through it. 

The Bad:  This game is enigmatic in it's reveal of the 'deeper' story. Even after finding extra secrets and puzzles to unlock hidden lore, I had no idea what was being alluded. However, I don't mind too much because I don't need a full understanding of the situation to enjoy the experience. After all I just finished Returnal.

The Ugly:  Kevin Saxby's performance was off the mark for the tone of the game. But I assume there was no acting director to guide him so I'll blame that for his short falling of performance. Where I would hope for his character to have taken the situation as more dire and freakish (especially as things progress), character Luke Carder came off like a sassy college girl who spies on her boyfriend and fights with his ex's. Basically like Billy Eichner on the Street. I loved the usage of live footage but Saxby's performance made it almost too comedic and disjointing from the rest of the vibe.

Daniel Mullins has got to be the most creative person in gaming. So many weird ideas, complex tricks, surprises, twists... you won't feel like this game takes the 10-15 hours to beat (not counting challenge runs) because it will honestly fly by.

Pros - Awesome concept, super cool art, very engaging story, tons of things that make you feel like you as a player have options.

Cons - the actual card game... isn't good. I've played a lot of card games, and this isn't a great one. The enemy doesn't follow any set of rules, so while you have to sacrifice or build energy, or whatever, the enemy just... does. They can put down an enemy on round one you would only be able to use on round 5. They can spawn multiple enemies whenever they want however they want. They have no energy, no sacrificing, nothing you have to do to summon and use cards. This is doubly frustrating because they have many of the cards you do, so while you struggle to find and summon a card, they can just... have a broken card whenever they want. If you are fighting a boss, rules go entirely out the window and the game follows a "You'll probably die first try because you didn't know the boss could turn all your cards into exploding fish cocktails when you beat his phase 1".

Once you do finally get a deck you like, the game changes and you basically reset and play a new, different, often worse, card game. Deck resets, kind of the same game but with new different rules. It's widely known in the later parts of the game you can just break the card came and pretty much autowin. In fact, the game is pretty poorly balanced. It's usually either struggling or crushing the opponent, and because they follow none of the normal rules, the feeling you would get from a normal card game like MTG, doesn't apply. Strategy is a case by case basis because you don't know what the AI will do (four enemies that explode on round 1? A guy that can do 3/5 of my life before I can respond?)

It's a good game, worth the price, but I feel weird saying it because the actual core gameplay, the card game, is just not well made. Or at least, choosing to let the AI not follow the rules makes it bad.

[h1] Not what it seems [/h1]

So this game was recommended to my by quite a few people since its release in 2021. Almost everyone I who played this game didn't want to talk about it that much in order to not spoil the plot. Well after watching some trailers and gameplay I thought I would give it a shot. [i] Deckbuilder meets Horror/Thriller? [/i] Count me in!

So after launching the game for the first time I am greeted with a really well made spooky, intriguing and fun setting. You are placed in a dark cabin in the woods with no information or clues of how you got there whatsoever. All you know is you need to play a card game against this mysterious man on the far side of the table.

[b] Let me make it clear that everything in act 1 is so incredibly well done! [/b]
Soon some of your cards start talking to you. You notice you can stand up from the table and move rather freely in the cabin you are held hostage in. There are a few puzzles there that give of a very interesting escape room vibe.
So you play, talk and puzzle your way through the mysteries presented to you. Every riddle solved only leads to further questions in your head.
All in all this part of the game is incredibly fun to play, solve and listen to.

[i] Sadly this only lasts for 3-4 hours. [/i]
After you defeat the old man you are presented with more information about the game and its story. Still great and captivating btw.

And then starts act 2.
The entire game you fell in love with in the first 4 hours is just [b] gone [/b].
[spoiler] You are now playing top down in a zelda/finalfantasy/stardewvalley-esque artstyle. The plot is kinda gone and you need to again get your bearings on what is happening. The gameplay itself is a card game again. Although very dumbed down from act 1. There are some new mechanics introduced but they really pale in comparison. 
So you battle your way to 4 main bosses in order to defeat them and replace one of them as scribe. All 4 boss "areas" are similar in esscence, thus getting boring really fast.  [/spoiler]
Someone played the first Assassins Creed? Get some informations 3 times -> kill main dude -> repeat.
This is fine to do if the gameplay is really fun, but not otherwise.

[spoiler] Sadly act 2 gameplay is really RNG in the beginning and once you get enough card packs it becomes too easy too fast and the whole story progressions gets tedious. Also the "puzzles" in act 2 are way easier than in act 1. Whereas act 1 had you wondering about the purpose of certain things act 2 is basically just: get hint -> go solve -> repeat, without any need to think about the puzzles.
To say this whole ordeal was a slog is putting it mildly. [/spoiler]

[b] However, this part only lasts for 1-2 hours max. So while I personally really didn't like it at least it was over quite fast! [/b]

[spoiler] So you beat all 4 bosses, return to the start and battle 1 final boss. Actually I am not sure at this point if there are different outcomes depending on who you choose/how you play out the battle, but the plot felt very forced to me.
>> I chose to replace PO3 and failed (?) the battle by attacking the corrupted card he played (had a mantis with 3-strike beside it and no way to sacrifice it).<<

So after a short cutscene, that really should have a epilepsy warning, you are now in act 3.

As of now I have only sunk about 50 minutes into this next act. It is, as was act 2, very different from the act 1 I liked so much. In short, almost 50% of what I played so far wasn't act 1 material. And neither act 2 not act 3 are fun to me. There is no mystery anymore, except from wanting to know how luke carder ends up in the end. Although he will probably get shot since that is what was being hinted at at the beginning of the game..
I really don't know if I will finish this game, since act 3 seems to be more of what I hated about act 2. [/spoiler]

Also I don't want to be that guy since I understand the novelty in having different games in 1 game which you, the consumer doesn't expect. However since way more than 50% of this game doesn't resemble the marketing material this is kinda false advertising?
I guess I won't be returning this game since I can respect the design decisions made by the developers. However as of now this game is just not for me since I can't be bothered to sit through multiple hours of gameplay I don't like, to watch an ending I can kinda predict.

[b] So as I said. Interesting game, objectively well made and thought out. Just not for me.
Also you should refrain from buying the game based solely on marketing material from act 1. I would have actually prefered some minor spoilers before buying to be sure act 2 and 3 were also something I enjoy. [/b]

A card game with a very entertaining story tied to various roguelite systems.
The story is rather spooky; although because of the repetitiveness of the roguelite systems, the player will get used to it rather fast.
The game stays fresh through the whole story and once you're done you have a decent amount of challenges to complete with incremental customisable difficulty.

The spooky part is very appreciated as it is not just the story but also the visuals and the music that manage to find the right balance for the player to take it seriously.
Along with this spooky story that is rather alarming at first, the game has plenty of humor to deliver.

This very dynamic combination along with the many surprises, puzzles, immersive ambiance, clever card systems, and difficulty, you'll most likely love the ride.

Inscyption is your standard rogue-lite card game, how it sets itself apart from the pack and why it has received such positive reception isn‚Äôt just its great elements but also its very special narrative.
 
The immersion here is world class, especially for the first act. The art style, sound design and atmosphere created one of the most immersive tutorials I have ever experienced. Its vivid, captivating and played on a few horror elements. The immersion and world building is by far Inscryption‚Äôs strongest card and this holds true throughout the rest of the acts. Sadly, the actual card game here can only be described as shallow and a little tedious, and its shallowness only increases the further in you go. The first act was fine but it was pretty obvious that the further in you go its intensity only increases, if you are buying Inscryption for its cards you might be disappointed. But none of this really matters because Inscryption isn‚Äôt really a card game.

Trying to explain what makes this game so special would be doing it a disservice. Inscryption plays on the element of surprise, more than any other game I‚Äôve ever played. I wish I could forget this game entirely so I could experience playing it again for the first time! I spent about 25 hours on the main game and the rest of the time was spent in Kaycee's Mod. This game is excellent, and I don't want to spoil it as it's very fun to experience without knowing what the heck is going on, but it's a card game with three chapters. Each chapter is wildly different than the last with the core card game remaining the same throughout. It can be a bit spooky at times, but nothing overtly scary. A few puzzles are sprinkled in, so while it is a card game you'll be walking around a very small amount as well. 

This made it into my top 10 favorite games of all time. Definitely worth buying & playing!

Inscription one of the best games I played all year, I have played pokemans and M.T.G before but don't consider myself a player of deck building card games, but something about a mysterious serial killer forcing me to play with with him (at threat of my life) both feels reminiscent of every other time I was forced (by a friend) to play such a game but also recontextualizes my frustration while learning the rules into something akin to the subtel cosmic horror of coming to realize the vastness of a system is vast and beyond your mortal comprehension to which you are but a insect doomed to be squashed (#relatable). This game is very good and teaching you how to play with a tutorial that blends seamlessly with exposition of the game setting. It is also super dense, much more content then it seems at first glance. The gameplay is at your own pace with play only moving to your opponents turn when you choose to end your turn, which makes it great for play with backseat gamers!

Just finished the main game and I loved it. BUT I'm mad.

I started playing Inscription about a year ago and got through most of act 3 until the game erased all save data just because I wanted to change my game language.
I don't understand why the "Delete Save Data" button in settings gets 3 extra confirmation messages, while changing the language only takes one click. It didn't help that the dev team didn't respond to my email. Considering this is a UX/UI issue and can be simply fixed with a popup window. 
So after the initial shock and grief I left the game alone for a year until I picked it back up recently because it took me this long just to feel fresh enough to restart.

TL;DR the game reset my saves because I wanted to change the game language. Got so sad I left the game for year and got back just recently and finished the game cuz it is a really phenomenal game. I wouldn't have felt so mad back then if I didn't truly enjoy the game.
